name: Der Präsident. -
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 17 July 2014 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: I have the sad announcement that our former member Ian Paisley died last Friday at the age of 88. He was a Member of this Parliament for 25 years in 1979 and First Minister in Northern Ireland at the end of his career. Ladies and gentlemen! I would like to inform you that several Members have drawn my attention to this: in these minutes we are once again receiving dramatic reports of refugee disasters in the Mediterranean. 250 refugees are believed to have died in a boating accident off the Libyan coast. 36 may be saved, but there are probably 250 dead. A tragedy has occurred off Malta, possibly killing 500 people. I share this because we have a moral duty to do everything possible to prevent such humanitarian disasters from happening, which we certainly cannot afford. Ladies and gentlemen! I told you last week, and I would like to repeat this now, that a so-called 360-degree recording is taking place here on Wednesday, just before the vote. Above all, for the pictures in our Parliamentarium, all Members here in the Chamber are once photographed by an all-round camera. You know that. Once a 360-degree shot is taken. Please be all there, because for many people who use the modern technical facilities, this is an opportunity to see where you are, as an MEP or as a Member, sitting here in the Chamber, where you are. Our visitors, who are in Parliament's visitor centre, can then also locate all their Members individually. So: Wednesday, noon 360-degree recording!

name: Der Präsident. -
text: I would now ask you to pay attention to an important formal process, ladies and gentlemen, which I must read to you in full for reasons of legal certainty. So, make yourself comfortable, that takes a bit. As I informed you by e-mail on 5 September, we will elect a new Ombudsman in accordance with Rule 219 of the Rules of Procedure. I would now like to explain to you the course of the electoral process. A call for nominations was published in the Official Journal on 2 September 2014. The nominations must be submitted by 30 September at the latest. According to Rule 219(2) of the Rules of Procedure, candidates must meet a number of conditions. I would just like to remind you of the provisions that directly affect you: each candidacy must be supported by at least 40 Members from at least two Member States. It is not possible to support multiple candidacies at the same time. If a member supports several candidacies with his or her signature, his or her signature does not count for any of these candidacies, which may result in such a candidacy being not permitted. As soon as I have been notified of a candidacy, it is no longer possible to add a signature to support or withdraw a signature. So once you've made up your mind, you've made up your mind. Pursuant to Rule 219(3) of the Rules of Procedure, I will forward to the Committee on Petitions the nominations which meet all the criteria laid down. It is likely to hold hearings of the candidates in December. These hearings of the Committee on Petitions are open to all members. The election will take place during the January 2015 plenary session. The services of the Directorate-General for the Presidency are, of course, at your disposal for any further questions.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 11 September 2014 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendment has been requested to this draft: Wednesday: the ALDE Group is asking for a debate on statements by the Council and the Commission on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary to be included as the first item on Wednesday afternoon's agenda. Mrs in't Veld has the floor to justify this.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Hungary is certainly not the only country where violations of the rule of law and fundamental rights take place, but we had debates earlier and are very concerned about recent statements by the Prime Minister and the raids on offices of NGOs. I know it has been proposed to debate this issue in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, but I think it is much wider than that, and also concerns other committees. We feel it would be appropriate to have a debate here in plenary to show the citizens that we stand for the protection of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, we hear every day our fellow citizens criticising Europe because it is not democratic enough, because in the end it does not apply to itself the values it professes outside. Indeed, I think that the case that has been raised by the ALDE group, which we support, is particularly emblematic. We sometimes have the impression that we have somehow imported Vladimir Putin's son or nephew within the European Union itself. I think this is a subject worth discussing, not only in the LIBE committee, but also in plenary.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the People's Group is not opposed to the debate, we are just saying that it must be done where it belongs in regulation. There has already been talk in plenary about Hungary and it has been done many times. The truth is that there is no new fact to justify bringing the matter back into plenary just because we are on the eve of an election in that country. There is an agreement in the LIBE Commission, of all the coordinators of the LIBE Commission, for this to be debated there, and an agreement of the Conference of Presidents to be debated in the LIBE Commission. The House should not depose the committees from its powers without a very justifiable cause. Yes, we have to debate, but we have to debate where it belongs, not where it doesn't play.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D). -
text: Mr President, my group shares the concern expressed by the Liberal Group and the Greens about the situation in Hungary. In fact, the evolution of this situation is even more serious, because in the last legislature we already had to deal with it. I don't think it's true, as has just been pointed out, that there are no new developments. There are. And worrying: attacks on non-governmental organizations and other bankruptcy of democratic rights. I therefore believe that this Parliament has to debate this issue, but I do not think it is time to take it to the House. My group will support a debate in plenary immediately after - and as soon as possible - another debate is being carried out in the Committee on Civil Liberties, with the participation of social partners and non-governmental organisations.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission on the impact of the Russian Federation's ban on imports of agricultural and food from the EU on European agriculture by Czeslaw Adam Siekierski on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000063/2014 - B8-0032/2014)-(2014/2835(RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: Author. - (C) Mr President, I would like to begin by thank Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In early August, the Russian Federation imposed an embargo on imports of agricultural and food products from the Union in retaliation for our sanctions against Russia as a result of Russia's role in the crisis and hostilities in Ukraine. The import embargo is the cause of significant losses on the part of our producers. In some sectors, such as fruit, vegetables and cheese and butter, around a third of our Union's exports have been affected and producers who have not been and are unable to sell their products will suffer losses and some may even go bankrupt.  The Committee on Agriculture considers it necessary to supplement its debate with an oral question addressed to the European Commission in the hope of a broader debate with the Commissioner on the plenum. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Our committee welcomes the action taken by the European Commission following the introduction of the embargo. However, we believe that the financial resources allocated for this purpose are far from sufficient in view of the scale and impact of the embargo on our producers. Moreover, as this crisis is primarily of a political nature and has not arisen as a result of market collapse or inauspicious weather conditions, solidarity from other sectors is necessary. Parliament's Committee on Agriculture is convinced that the burden of the financial assistance required to help affected farmers should not be borne entirely from the agricultural budget line and that additional appropriations from other budget lines could be made available.  Dear! It was also reported that aid to the fruit and vegetables sector was suspended last week as the requests for support collected exceeded the available limit. In countries where farmers are not affiliated and products are bought from them by intermediaries, farmers often report the entire area of crops because they do not know what part of the production goes to export, including to Russia, and what to the domestic consumption. The majority of farmers, especially small farmers, in the new Member States do not yet belong to producer groups or industry associations, and therefore the level of support should not be differentiated between affiliated and non-attached farmers. It is important to rethink the launch of the next stage of collecting notifications from farmers, which is not contrary to the closure and evaluation of applications, because the situation in this respect is dynamic.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. On behalf of the AGRI Committee, we would like to ask you to provide Members of the European Parliament with up-to-date information on the actions already taken and planned by the European Commission. Do you intend to complete the first set of actions? Strengthen them? Increase the financial resources assigned to them and potentially extend their scope to include additional sectors, e.g. the meat sector? In particular, do you intend to introduce special compensatory measures for those holdings that may be at risk of bankruptcy?

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all thank you very much for creating this opportunity to hold a debate on a subject which is important, which has the attention of the European Commission, that is, the impact of this Russian embargo on the European agricultural sector, agri-food and on the European market. The embargo imposed by Russia at the beginning of August affects three major agricultural sectors of the Union: fruits and vegetables, the dairy sector and the meat sector.   To put this in context, I would like to point out that Russia is the second largest export market for the European agri-food sector and that exports to Russia account for about 10% of the European Union's exports. But for some sectors and especially for the sectors mentioned, the Russian market accounts for about a third of what the European Union exports, mainly for fruits and vegetables and dairy products and sometimes even for meat. Exports covered by the embargo amount to 5 billion euros and earn the incomes of millions of farmers in the European Union. We are therefore facing a European crisis to which a proportionate but coherent and effective response must be given. The tools of the reformed common agricultural policy that we just adopted together a few years ago give us the means to react in a coherent, united and rapid way. That is why I decided to act quickly, as early as August, as soon as these measures were announced, in particular on three axes.  First of all, our aim was to avoid the destabilisation of the European market by products that would no longer be exported and which risked returning to the European market and thus leading to price falls. A second objective of the measures envisaged was to support European sectors in the search for new markets. While we recognize that this may take time, it is important to give producers a signal and support as quickly as possible so that they begin to diversify export markets. The third objective of our measures was to open the debate on the question of possible targeted compensation, as the sector is asking for and as mentioned in the question you have raised, taking into account of course the political and financial implications of the compensation that we can envisage. With regard to the first package of measures, i.e. the rapid stabilisation of the market following Russia's decision, the Commission opted for immediate responses in the two sectors that were immediately affected by this Russian decision, the fruit and vegetable sector and the dairy sector. For these two sectors, exports to Russia, as I have already said, account for about one third of total European exports. Fruits and vegetables were the first emergency, since we have perishable products here that cannot be stored and for which solutions had to be proposed quickly in order to prevent prices from falling and therefore the incomes of all fruit and vegetable producers at European level to be affected. Measures were put in place on 11 August for the fisheries and nectarine sector and, a week later, on 18 August, we were able to offer a wider package for other particularly perishable fruits and vegetables of which Russia was a key buyer. These exceptional measures benefited from a budget of 125 million euros, with a ceiling of 82 million euros for apples and pears and a ceiling of 43 million euros for a number of other fruits and vegetables. We calculated this amount on the basis of, among other things, the quantities exported to Russia that we assumed should be withdrawn from the market in one way or another, but we also provided an additional margin in case there were any indirect effects. We therefore proposed measures to withdraw from the market by encouraging free distribution, but also measures to harvest in green or not to harvest certain crops that could not be sold.  Since the notifications of Member States covering the period from 18 August to 3 September for the proposed transactions exceeded these ceilings, the Commission had to decide, in accordance with the delegated act, to suspend this measure. I can assure you, as I have already announced publicly, that we are not considering stopping there, we are aware that there will be other products that we will have to target in the fruit and vegetable sector. The Commission is in the process of preparing a new measure for this sector, which I hope we will be able to announce as early as this week. My services are now working with other Commission departments to present this proposal, which I can assure you will also be substantial in view of the realities of the market. This will probably be a more targeted measure to prevent notifications that are not justifiable.  For the dairy sector, as soon as the first signs of an impact on this sector appeared, I decided to activate the safety net provided in the market management regulation by supplementing with exceptional measures. Thus, aid is now available for the private storage of dairy products that can be stored: this is butter, low-fat milk powder, but also some cheeses. In parallel with this private storage which was triggered we also decided to extend the public intervention until the end of the year for powdered milk and butter, which was normally to stop on 30 September, in case products were to be withdrawn from the market.  In the meat sector, the situation is more nuanced since Russia had already placed European pork under embargo since the beginning of the year, due to swine fever in some parts of the European Union. Operators have found some new opportunities in Asia, along with domestic production that has been limited as a result.  In the beef sector, production and consumption have been in structural decline for some time, which can lead to a degree of fragility in the sector and market balance, despite growing global demand. The closure of the Russian market requires an intensification of ongoing efforts to open other markets that remain closed due to unjustified health barriers and which could also provide a response for this sector in the medium term. For this meat sector, I have asked my services to follow up closely. If the market situation in producer prices or margins shows signs of destabilization, we are also prepared to react because we have the necessary instruments. I would also like to tell you that the Commission is constantly looking at market developments and the impact of the measures that have been taken, sector by sector. I decided to set up a Task Force within DG AGRI in early August to monitor this market. Since August, we have been holding weekly meetings with experts from Member States to monitor market developments and make decisions on this basis as quickly as possible. This rapid reaction by the Commission was possible in part thanks to the delegated powers that Parliament and the Council granted to the Commission as part of the CAP reform. Remember, we discussed with some of you the need for a rapid response by the Commission in times of crisis. The fact that we were able to react quickly proves that what we decided in the reform of the CAP on the "market management" part seems to work because by taking immediate action, we limit both the cost to the budget and the losses to producers.  Alongside these immediate market management actions, we also need to prepare for the future. That is why we are now paying particular attention to actions to find new markets, in particular to promotional actions in markets outside the European Union. For this reason, the Commission has decided to double the budget envelope for the funding of promotional programmes that were planned for a round of projects due to close on 30 September. We had originally provided EUR 30 million in Eu funding for these packages under the promotion programme. We have added another EUR 30 million, which means EUR 60 million in Community funding, plus private funding. We will therefore have a package of EUR 120 million which will be able to finance promotional actions fairly quickly and help the agri-food sector to move to other markets. What measures is the Commission planning to take in the future? In addition to these market stabilization measures that we have taken and can take if necessary, we are also considering the possibility of providing targeted compensation to producers, in particular to prevent the disappearance of agricultural enterprises that would be perfectly profitable in a normal market situation, and of course related jobs. This issue of compensation involves a real political discussion, since we need to look at two things: first, how to target the categories of beneficiaries who could get these compensations because we have to go to those who really need it, those who are really affected, by farm category but also by sector; how to ensure the financial coverage of these compensations.  Some of you have asked to fund these measures not from the CAP budget but from other budgets. I would like to tell you, but my colleague in charge of the budget will probably also have the opportunity to say that we cannot do anything other than within the margins of the budget provided by Parliament. You know that the margins of the budget that we have are very small. We are currently using the margins we have on the CAP budget. We also have that crisis reserve. We must therefore hold this political discussion to see not only where to direct these compensations but also how to finance them, given budgetary constraints and budgetary constraints. The Commission believes that this decision should be taken as quickly as possible, since for financial compensation to be useful, it must arrive quickly with farmers. I would like to avoid the situation we had during the dairy crisis in 2009, when financial compensation for dairy farmers was decided one year after the crisis: for some producers the money came too late.  In the coming months, according to the assessment of the impact we are going to make with the Member States, but in a targeted way, this decision will have to be taken. I want you to know that the Commission is open, but we need this political discussion that we have to have on the budget allocation in order to support these kinds of measures.  Those are the topics that I wanted to put to your analysis, to your debate and of course depending on the questions you will ask and other topics that you will raise, I will be ready to answer at the end.

name: elnök asszony. -
text: Thank you very much for the Commissioner's very detailed and detailed response. Now it is up to the political groups to make their key words. Firstly, I would like to call Mr Deß from the European People's Party. Order me, Congressman, you have the word in two minutes.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to begin by saying that today's discussion is a consequence of Putin's and Russia's annexation of Crimea, which is contrary to international law, and also of the unspoken war that Russia is waging against Ukraine. Thank God, the response from the EU and Western states was not tanks and soldiers, but boycottmeasures against Putin and his regime. Russia was expected to respond with countermeasures. The boycott of food from the European Union and other partner countries has different effects. There are countries and areas that are very much affected. I would like to thank the Commission, and especially you, Commissioner Ciolos, for their quick response and the announcement of aid to affected farmers and businesses. You have just listed a whole bar of measures. There is an urgent need for aid, particularly in the Baltic States, Poland and some other countries. It is now necessary not to help according to a watering can principle, but very specifically. The resources available in the budget are certainly not enough to help, at least where a situation that threatens their own existence has occurred through no fault of their own. The situation shows that the EU has budgeted far too little money for crisis situations. We need reallocations in the budget. I also say this as a farmer: if the resources are not sufficient, the solidarity of all farmers is also required to use direct means of payment to help their colleagues who are at risk of their livelihoods. Particularly reprehensible is the behaviour of large retail chains, which immediately abused the Russian boycott measures and exerted price pressure on food producers. It is interesting that EU consumers are the winners of the boycott measures, as food prices fall. That is why it is also responsible to use taxpayers' money to help those affected so that their livelihoods are not jeopardised. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Des, would you not agree that the Member States should now also be allowed to activate their national aid programmes? We need approval from Brussels, including consolidation loans, liquidity loans and aid programmes.  Secondly, would it not finally be time to properly reduce the school milk and school fruit programmes, so that we could finally get more products into schools in this way?

name: Albert Deß (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, Mr Peter Jahr. It is, of course, necessary, before asking for help from Brussels, that all national programmes be applied for and exhausted. You have pointed out a number of measures, there are others: taxes can be deferred for those affected, there are many measures. It would be particularly important, Commissioner Ciolos, for the school milk and school fruit programme to be massively debureaucratised. This would be a good way to quickly find sales for fruit and vegetables and also for dairy products. Many people do not use this programme because it is far too bureaucratic. Something needs to be changed quickly here, and this can also help to defuse the situation.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the crisis with Russia is a political crisis, but so far it is mainly European farmers who are paying the consequences. The resources made available to the Commission – and here I too would like to add my thanks to Commissioner Cioloş – one hundred and twenty-five million euros, are certainly a timely response, but it is totally insufficient to compensate for the considerable damage to our producers, especially if the European Union continues to issue sanctions and Russia continues to respond by extending the embargo. A dramatic ping-pong for our farmers. I would also like to point out that, in order to give the scale of the problem, we need only mention 39% of European fruit and vegetable exports to Russia or 33% of european cheese exports to Russia. We are therefore asking the Commission for more money to deal with a crisis which, unfortunately, is not seen to end quickly. However, it is important to remember that these resources must not be taken from the crisis reserve of the agricultural budget. I would like to remind you of this, as the Commissioner has partly said, because because of the agreement on the financial perspectives, those funds have in fact been wiped out. Therefore, drawing funds from the crisis reserve actually means cutting direct aid to farmers. If the crisis is political, farmers are clearly not to blame for the financial burden of the Russian embargo. Ladies and gentlemen, we must be able to find other funds from the European budget that go beyond the agricultural budget.  Finally, I would like to point out that the commission's halt to the disbursement of funds following disproportionate requests from some Member States shows that a more rational method must be found than simply first come-first served in order to distribute compensatory aid in a balanced way as has been done on other occasions, I am thinking of escherichia coli.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, first of all thank you for agreeing to include this question of the Russian import ban today and for accepting the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development initiated by the ECR Group, and especially the Polish delegation, the Law and Justice Party, in this group. Six years ago the Polish President, Lech Kaczynski, organised successful political action in Tbilisi against the Russian invasion of Georgia. He said at the time that it was Georgia today, Ukraine tomorrow, the Baltic States the day after tomorrow and then Poland. Now we have gone one step further: Georgia yesterday, Ukraine today, the Baltic States tomorrow, and Poland the day after tomorrow. Economic sanctions are the best way to stop the aggressive and imperial policy of Russia, but sanctions are costly for both sides. The highest price is paid by farmers, especially those from the eastern part of the EU – from neighbouring countries like Finland, the Baltic States and my country, Poland. We need European solidarity. The cost of the sanctions should be paid by the whole Union, not only by farmers and immediate neighbours. Commissioner, my question is, although we have a financial reserve for the crisis (we have a serious crisis – not a disturbance, but a crisis), why was the reserve under Article 25, Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, not used? Why was this reserve not used? We need to use it. Why was the proposal of the Polish Government on this not accepted? Please answer. European farmers are waiting for real support and real help. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask the Member: he has stated that he considers economic sanctions to be the best means of improving the situation and for the security of Ukraine. I would like to ask how you see the result of the economic sanctions applied so far. Do you consider that these sanctions have helped to find a solution? Have you brought the situation in Ukraine closer, security? Or maybe the opposite, they've escalated the situation. I ask you to respond to this on the basis of the experience of sanctions.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Yes, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work I believe that consistently applied economic sanctions can effectively stop Russia's imperial, aggressive policies. This was the case in the past, when Ronald Reagan's policy of firmly applying economic sanctions led to the collapse of the imperial power of the former Soviet Union. Today, putin's imperial policy can be stopped by consistent economic sanctions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, in this case the Commission has responded really swiftly and well to the embargo imposed by Russia, the assistance given directly or indirectly is absolutely necessary and there is clearly a political will in this House to fully support this Commission policy. Exports to Russia as a percentage seemingly not even great. For some countries, however, it is extremely large, and for any farmer experiencing a disaster, of course, its survival is also questioned. That is why I ask the Commission what we will do if the embargo persists, what kind of response we have strategicly to this issue, and I propose that new markets be searched first, that we go aggressively to new markets and it is good that we invest in marketing in this regard. Secondly, to really involve all member states and member states of the European Union and thirdly, to actually "use" this, to implement and bring fruit to schools.  Finally, I want to say that the embargo refers to the products we are about to pick, including in many Mediterranean countries, we will soon be picking tangerines and other products, and I hope that the Commission will have the same attitude towards these products as it has so far. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, I have listened closely to your presentation. I wonder if you personally think and believe that these economic sanctions can affect the imperialist policy of Russia and whether farmers are the ones who have to feel the sanctions first, and here I especially mean farmers from Croatia. You mentioned tangerines. The commissioner just said it's not perishable fruit, citrus fruits are exempt. How can we influence citrus fruits to enter this category and that citrus fruits also become perishable fruits, because they are.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Šuica, it is a political crisis, so it is about the fact that politics has led, in this particular case, russia's policy to this situation. We're talking politics here. We are talking about agricultural producers and if there is political will, and it seems to me that there is a political will in this house to get all farmers who will be in trouble due to the fact that we have an embargo, I believe that it can be helped even when it comes to citrus fruits.  I think the Commission has shown this so far and I expect it to continue this policy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the European peasants are the victim of a decision which we have not taken. We are the victim of an irresponsible decision that the European Union has made, we know, to promote the interests of the United States Government. But this crisis also shows the insecurity and economic fragility in which current European policy has plunged the peasant in the European Union: a common agricultural policy with an export vocation and from there we now have this situation. We believe that it is urgent right now that aid reaches the peasantry, all peasants without discrimination, all production sectors – all production sectors are affected by this crisis – and also that aid is sufficient to cover production costs and also peasant labour. But we urgently need, Commissioner, to open a debate for a new CAP, a CAP which puts the rights and interests of the peasant, the life of the peasant, which puts the centre at the centre of... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker) (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – You said here that it was an irresponsible decision taken by the Commission. I would like you to explain to us what the decision you were proposing would have been.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – I believe that, as I said, the Commission's irresponsibility is already coming from behind, from an exporting policy which led us to these conclusions. That is why I believe that it is urgent, for example, in the dairy sector, to reverse and put an end to this decision to abandon quotas. I also believe that we must move towards a policy that establishes mechanisms for publicly managing supply, and also towards a policy that ensures that peasants are going to charge the right prices for our work. In short, a common agricultural policy within the framework of food sovereignty.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank the Commission for taking swift action.  This is where European solidarity is needed. Just as we have jointly adopted the sanctions, now that there is a backlash, we must act together as Europeans. That is why the Commission's action here is to be welcomed.  There are different concerns in the Member States. Of course, the Baltic States, Poland and others are most affected, but also producers of southern fruits who have lost their markets. But the whole thing now also meets a situation of falling prices, which were already there before. But we are now almost forced to see that farmers are not left alone now. Stabilizing markets is a measure. But I would warn against exporting our problems to other countries, so to speak, and sending surpluses somewhere where they are not desirable. In other words, it cannot now be a solution that we may end up thinking about export refunds again, but that we must resolve the situation within Europe.  We must, of course, also look closely at where the aid is now arriving. It is necessary – apparently also because the Commission initially suspended it – to look twice carefully at who is really in need now and who is getting the money. There are free-riders in this area, and it is not acceptable that we are now paying money out to people who may not need it at all. Of course, we also need a policy that prevents trade from capitalising on it and pushing prices down even further. Allow me also to say a word about the export orientation of European agricultural policy. We Greens have always warned against relying only on exports, but we must look in the long term to serve the European market and not rely on such unreliable partners, which in the end ultimately drag us all into the abyss. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – (PT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing here the direct damage to the people of the European Union, to European farmers, of a situation which I believe was created by the irresponsibility of the leaders of the Union. There was a political problem in which the European Union has declared an economic war, and we are now discussing the damage of that war. The question I ask is this: is it not to find a political solution to the political problem that led to this economic war, rather than deepening the consequences? Because, Mr President, what do I think, following the polish colleague's methodology, yesterday was a political war, it was a political problem, today it is an economic war, tomorrow what war will it be?

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I think you are confusing cause and effect here.  The aggressor must be clearly identified and the European Union must act in solidarity with this. I believe that the European Union has never shown more solidarity than it has been in imposing sanctions. If there is a backlash, then solidarity is also required from the European Union. I would not say now, on the grounds that there are those affected here in the European Union, that is why the European Union's policy of sanctions was wrong. On the contrary, how else should we have acted?  The fact that there are now industries such as farmers affected by this, in turn, requires our intra-European solidarity in order to mitigate the impact on those affected. I can only welcome the way in which the European Union has acted.

name: Marco Zullo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have seen that the value of the agri-food products affected by the Russian embargo is estimated by the European Commission at EUR five billion and affects the income of nine and a half million European producers, nine and a half million families. Unfortunately, this assessment is optimistic. For Italy alone, the figure indicated of one hundred and sixty million euros is less than the two hundred million calculated by the trade associations. Optimistic assessment because indirect consequences such as triangulation trade, which affects European products sold to Russia via third countries, are not considered. Optimistic assessment because the long-term loss of market share is not considered, because the Russian consumer could get used to other tastes and no longer take back European products. Optimistic assessment because imbalances in the internal market are not taken into account, due to the introduction of low-cost products that no longer find an outlet on the Russian market will be poured onto the European market. It is therefore very likely that the aid allocated, which is already lower than necessary, will not be sufficient. The 5-Star Movement calls on the European Commission in future measures to provide for a more careful distribution of resources and to work to finally build a genuine harmonised European single market capable of absorbing shocks and emergencies, managing internal trade flows in a forward-looking way. Either we all work to create a real Europe system, or it means that if it is only emergencies that dictate the guidelines, we can afford to say that the European institutions are failing in their task.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI). -
text: Madam President, I would just like to point out that this agricultural policy, which I think is ill-prepared and does not correspond to the desired purpose, is long-term. It must be understood that Russia has recently prepared agreements with Brazil, Argentina and Latin American countries to, once and for all, no longer depend on these productions... (The President interrupts the speaker) Has the Commission underserearned in the long term that these aids are not ad hoc but will probably be sustainable? Do the officials who made those decisions here agree that, in a year's time, farmers know that the long-term situation depends on their decisions?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI). -
text: Madam President, in a European Union, whose many Member States are plagued by the economic crisis, the imposition of an embargo by Russia, mainly on agricultural products and other products, is the tip of the iceberg. As Greek citizens, we are concerned and are monitoring developments regarding the embargo on my country's products, which is having a negative and direct impact on our national economy at a difficult juncture, as it is today. The consequences and consequences of the Russian blockade are chained. Surplus food will remain untapped, at the risk of crushing commodity prices. Already humiliatingly low prices will suffer a greater reduction and the effects of speculation will be immediate and visible. It is unacceptable to target troubled economies, such as the Greek one, and to charge the price of the Russian-Ukrainian crisis. The great political and business interests started this crisis in our absence, always in the name of democracy and freedoms, and we are now discussing solutions to repair the damage to cancer-stricken economies like that of my country.  Third countries, including NATO members who participate in European policy, benefit from the costs already paid by the Member States. Compensation with Community money cannot be a political strategy. We need a new policy, a strategic approach between the European Union and Russia, we need to strengthen our corporate and trade relations. The facts call for a revision and a change in the policy applied. The continuation of the conflict with Russia will bring more suffering and problems than benefits for the Member States of the Union.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE). -
text: Madam President, aggression against Ukraine is an extremely serious threat to peace in Europe. It must be understood that it is not a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, it is an aggression of the Russian Federation and a threat to all Member States, whether they are in the east or in the west of the Union. Unfortunately, I don't think Russia will stop. Republic of Moldova, the mouths of the Danube can be the future targets. A military conflict is not a solution. Economic and political sanctions are the only weapon that can be used. A firm and common attitude of all Member States is needed. Differences of opinion between Member States do not lead to a resolution of the situation. Although sanctions, such as those in the agricultural sector, also have negative effects on the Union economy, I am convinced that the Union has the capacity to minimise such effects and to take the necessary measures, both clearing and targeting in other markets. The new common agricultural policy has the necessary budgetary and legal tools to support producers. I too add my thanks to the Commissioner, both for agricultural policy and for the measures taken very quickly. It is important for the Union to take joint decisions, which are not dependent on individual interests but on Community interests, and which lead to a resolution of the situation as quickly as possible.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate you on your responsiveness on the Russian embargo, in order to deal with the consequences that European agriculture may suffer.  Unfortunately, once again, fishing is the great forgotten part of the Union's food policies. However, the Russian embargo will affect European fishermen worth an estimated 144 million euros. Your colleague, Commissioner Damanaki, has informed us that some of the BUDGET lines of the EMFF, including the funds provided for storage, could be used by fishermen who are victims of the embargo. But unlike agriculture, no additional means are currently allocated to fishing. This failure would lead to the sacrifice of essential projects such as selectivity to avoid rejections or direct selling, which should have been financed from these same amounts. Commissioner, how can we justify the uneven treatment of two sectors, which are comparable. Can we not have a coordinated position to treat these two food sectors fairly?  I have tabled with my group a series of amendments calling for an exceptional increase in the 2015 budget for fisheries, as is the case with agriculture. I hope that we can count on the support of the Commission. To be firm in relation to the outside, you have to be supportive on the inside.

name: Beata Barbara Gosiewska (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I come from Polish, a region where poor agriculture has been particularly affected by the Russian embargo, and I will say this: Putin is pleased because the European Commission cannot take effective action to prevent the Russian embargo. The Commission should provide real support to farmers, not create the illusion that it is taking action. There is no doubt that the resources that the Commission wanted to allocate to compensate farmers affected by the Russian embargo were ridiculously small from the outset. Last week's decision to stop accepting applications from farmers is scandalous and leaves them without any help. I do not understand, and on behalf of my constituents, I ask the Commission why, in the face of one of the most serious crises, it is not using the EU reserve for these purposes. From here, I also call on the Commission to take concrete and holistic action in the fight against a crisis that not only affects fruit producers, but also the dairy sector. In the current situation, the abolition of penalties for exceeding milk quotas is necessary. I repeat: necessary! The sanctions imposed on Russia are not effective and the European Union should therefore review its policy in this area and take decisive and solidarity-based action.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE). -
text: Commissioner, you yourself have demonstrated the seriousness of the situation on the European market in the figures. In monitoring the impact of the embargo on the European market, we necessarily conclude that it is necessary to significantly adapt both the short-term measures and our long-term trading strategy. Unfortunately, the European Commission's compensatory and other measures do not cover all affected businesses, and it is already clear that these measures will not be sufficient. It is clear that the embargo also has an impact on those companies that do not export directly to the Russian Federation. Therefore, when evaluating the measures taken, I ask you to take into account the overall effects both on the European Union single market, on the common agricultural policy and on the common commercial policy. At this point, your close cooperation with DG TRADE is necessary to avoid flooding the European market. It is necessary to look for non-European markets, not only for agriculture, but for all sectors affected by the embargo. We must have a plan B if such a situation were to happen again. Our businesses must not suffer when we have the tools to prevent this.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I believe that there is something much more important in foreign policy than everyone's ideology, and it is responsibility. And it gives me the impression that in recent months we have seen anything but responsibility: we have seen European leaders make warmongering speeches against Russia and we have seen them support illegal shifts of power in Ukraine, which have resulted, inter alia, in the neo-Nazi government of that country and for political parties to be outlined.  The consequences for European farmers are in a Russian veto equivalent to EUR 2 billion, while the European Commission provides for aid of only EUR 125 million. It's easy to hit your chest; it is easy to evoke, as we have heard in this House, nothing more and nothing less than Ronald Reagan, which is very "reassuring". What's going to be next? Remember the tragic time of the Euromisiles? I have no sympathy for Mr Putin, but I believe that the Union's foreign policy cannot be to play Risk with the interests of European farmers and that, for better or worse, Europeans deserve a peaceful and responsible relationship with Russia.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, unfortunately, the embargo with Russia has created serious problems for all farmers and it is not right that they should suffer the consequences. They are already suffering from the law that you approved with oranges from Morocco, so they are suffering so much from this crisis. This embargo has now caused even more serious problems. I would like to ask the Commission what it intends to do to help them. The aid you have given has not been sufficient. Furthermore, they have not been checked or disbursed on a rational basis. They have been distributed in the rain as you usually do, so it is not fair, as they are now finished and many have not received any compensation. So my colleagues are asking for more money: it is not right to disburse others without any criteria, without first assessing who really needs them, but distributing them is not known on what basis. We are calling for your system for the distribution of these compensations to be reassessed, for everyone to benefit from it and not just for certain countries in particular, and we call on the Commission to use this crisis constructively, that is to say, to use the overproduction of agricultural products so that it is distributed to schools as an educational programme for the use of fruit and vegetables.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what did the European Commission expect, that Putin's Russia would react with postcards of thanks for the measures taken? This policy of retaliation was largely predictable and, it was not difficult to understand, would have had a very serious impact on the very sensitive economy which affects the agri-food sector of our export of producing countries, including my own country. I stress the direct and indirect consequences present and also in the future – think only of the problem of Expo 2015. We, as the European Union, are witnessing a bit like Alice in Wonderland, that is the impression given by the representative of the European Commission. It speaks to us of very modest aid in the face of what may become a tragedy for agricultural production and milk production in the entire European sector, in the face of which It seems to me that the hesy, generality and weakness of the measures taken are really at odds with the superficiality with which, for example, the Renzi Government has not been able to discuss in advance with the European Commission the aid that would be and should be given to our producers.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. We are currently experiencing a deep crisis in our relations with Russia. Unfortunately, the farmers are currently paying the bill for this. I am convinced that sanctions are the right and probably the only sensible way to bring about improvements in this area. On the other hand, however, we should also bear in mind that, most likely, only decisive action on our part will also make the Russians give a backing. That is why some of the measures you have proposed, Commissioner, are absolutely right, but also inadequate. And the suspension of measures in recent days is not the right way either. I come from a region where around 10% of apples are produced in Europe. Combined with the fact that we are expecting a record harvest this year as well, it is currently the case that the price of fresh, now harvested apples is currently half that of a year ago. The damage suffered by our farmers can be calculated very clearly. That is why aid – and I am pleased that you have announced that new measures will follow in the next few days – should be resumed immediately and we should also resolutely address the situation with new and fresh funds.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we are in an important and very important debate for the European agri-food sector and, of course, for my country, Spain. The undeniable immediacy of the measures — with the response of the two Regulations we have seen during August — has not been as immediate to the fisheries sector as Mrs Thomas has referred to, since, although we have not seen any of these measures by her colleague Commissioner Damanaki, the immediacy you have taken in these measures is undeniable , but perhaps the result, of course, in my opinion, is not right. It is perhaps premature to make an overall loss estimate. What is clear is that there are no funds in the CAP that can mitigate or limit the impact that may occur. Among the Commission's valuations of EUR 5 billion and the 125 that the Commission has put in place for perishable products, there is a long way to go. Probably, Commissioner, the worst we haven't seen yet. I would like to emphasize that a special sensitivity towards continental productions is common and less towards Mediterranean productions. I did not think it was appropriate to determine to include perishable products on the list and others not, being in production, which leads to bewilderment and discrimination. We are now faced with the suspension of the Regulation, which needs to be put in place as soon as possible. We need to improve crisis mechanisms. I lived in my land, in Andalusia, the crisis of E. coli: how, unjustly, Andalusian agricultural productions were accused. And I saw what a crisis is and how long it takes to overcome it. But I want to tell you that we must also look at something that is happening with the great distribution. There's a market collapse. It has been given especially in the month of August, with price drops. But consumers don't see the lowest prices. Who is taking the benefit of this crisis? Maybe the big distribution? If the Russian veto were to be maintained, would you probably not consider reviewing partnership agreements and Community preferences?

name: Julie Girling (ECR). -
text: Madam President, of course we are all concerned about the impact on European farmers, I no less than anyone else. Even those Member States which are not heavily affected directly will be affected in time by market impacts such as falling prices. The ramifications of these political sanctions are very wide-reaching. We have been using the language of emergency and crisis, all of which implies a reaction to the unexpected. I would like to ask the Commissioner why the impact on farmers seems to have been so badly thought through. Is it a surprise that Russia has retaliated? No, of course not. Of course they would hit back in the area of fresh and perishable produce for maximum short-term impact. We hear about further sanctions being imposed by Brussels, so my question is: ‘What is the plan?’ Even if the EUR 430 million crisis reserve is mobilised it is not going to last long: we have already earmarked EUR 155 million in less than a month. Clearly, just calling for more and more financial support is not the answer: it cannot be, because that would simply be a bottomless pit. I would like to know from you, Commissioner, what the Commission’s medium-term and long-term plans are. Are you discussing this as a Commission? I know you are in a state of flux but are you actually looking clearly at the implications of foreign policy?

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for coming in. Commissioner, it is a pleasure to have you here. Colleagues, I am from a very small country: Lithuania. A lot of you have said today – surprisingly – that we need an alternative policy with Russia. If only we were diplomatic with them, they might stop. They might have forgotten to hit that plane in the sky that just fell down. No one has even talked about that plane. There were a lot of Dutch people on it.  Russia will not stop. Lithuanians will keep supporting sanctions until they stop. Russia will stop when they realise that we are united – that we are Europe together and that we will not tolerate losing a few million here and there. We will not tolerate them doing this to us, because we are united: we are a real Europe. Look at Eurostat – 20 % of agricultural exports to Russia are from Lithuania and we endorse these sanctions. We want more sanctions. We want Russia to stop in Ukraine. So, Commissioner, please consider declaring the Baltic States an area of specific need. Look at the direct European support to the Baltic States. We receive the least. Is it fair? It is time for Europe to wake up and unite and also to be fair. Commissioner, please consider this – and everybody, it is time to unite against Russia.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the ban imposed by the Russian Federation on agricultural products from the EU is a very worrying development. It reflects the failures of both Russian and European diplomacy that have impacted most on the people of Ukraine but will now undoubtedly be felt by farmers and businesses across the regions. The EU’s agri-food sector is in crisis and these sanctions will mean that those already struggling to survive will no longer be able to do so. Questions that therefore need to be addressed this evening by the Commission include: what further measures will the Commission take to ensure that our small family farmers do not pay the price for political decisions they did not ask for; will the crisis reserve cover their losses; and will compensation be put in place for scenarios where there is a long-term impact on farmers beyond the sanctions period? Small farmers now need a friend in the European Commission, not a bureaucracy which fails to act while their livelihoods suffer.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, deteriorating relations with Russia and the imposition of economic sanctions have hit the agricultural sector hard across the European Union. A particular problem for Croatia is the exclusion of mandarins from subsidised products. More than 2 000 family farms are directly affected by the sanctions, i.e. almost 20 000 people who are existentially attached to this production. Direct subsidies are never the best solution, especially if they are not distributed fairly. In emergency situations, the market is proving to be a bad steering wheel. In order to keep the money within the European Union, it is necessary to create demand on the European market by encouraging the purchase of fresh products and their processing within the Union. It is necessary to create instruments to indirectly stimulate the market with the aim of creating demand on the European market.  I have already brought to the Commission's attention that fresh products are in question and immediate measures are needed to allow fresh mandarins to be bought or processed into semi-durable or durable products in the EU internal market. Any other long-term measures are commendable, but too easy for this year's harvest.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, since last August Russia has blocked the import of European agricultural products, a measure that affects five billion euros of food that at least for a year cannot be sold in those countries. European producers therefore lose a valuable market and products remain unsold on the shelves. Tons of meat, milk, fruits and vegetables left to rot. But where there is a problem, you can normally also find an opportunity. The economic crisis and austerity have brought millions of Europeans below the poverty line, and Russian sanctions are threatening the survival of hundreds of small and medium-sized farms in Europe. Millions of people have nothing to eat, while tons of food rot on the shelves.  So I, Commissioner, as spokesperson for the 5-Star Movement, call on the Commission and the Member States to establish a serious and effective programme – serious and effective – for the purchase of food for charity. The funds are there, we can find them from the CAP budget, which provides for a reserve fund, and then they can be supplemented by the States. By a simple gesture, we can respond to millions of citizens affected by the crisis, and we can also respond to thousands of producers. There is only one question I am asking you: what are we waiting for, what are we discussing?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: I would have liked to ask my fellow Lithuanian Member how he knows for sure what happened to that particular machine. How do you know he was shot by the Russians, so to speak? It is a fact that the European Union has imposed these certain ill-considered sanctions on this. To which, of course, counter-protests have come, and the consequences of these counter-actions are suffered not by politicians, but by farmers. Hungary, I can say the following: Together with Hungary, several other Member States have already lost their Russian markets once, and then we have had a hard time rebuilding them. Now we've lost him again because of the ill-considered sanctions. That's one of our problems.  The other is that I would like to ask Mr Cioloş, the European Union Commissioner for Agriculture, about this. What is the guarantee that in the other 27 Member States, and in particular in the politically strong first-class central countries, the accumulated agricultural surpluses – surpluses of raw materials and processed food – will not be mass inflows into the markets of peripheral countries. And by doing so, they're putting our masters in a double wrath. How do they therefore wish to protect peripheral countries from landing agricultural products and crops accumulated by the central countries as a result of sanctions, putting farmers in an even more difficult situation. And I also ask that my Hungarian compatriots eat domestic food and express solidarity with farmers in difficulty.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I regret that my first speech in the House in this parliamentary term is to denounce the damage to the agricultural and livestock sector as a result of the embargo imposed by the Russian Government. I believe that the European Union should act in a more responsible way, bearing in mind that this is a very serious matter whose causes are totally alien to the sector. Emergency aid should be earmarked for those truly affected by this crisis, expanding to the sectors that are needed, such as citrus fruits now, and taking into account the cascading effect of some producers on others , and I am referring, for example, to mushrooms. It is in the public domain that the current suspension of aid is due to certain abuses identified in some Member State in the aid application process. This suspension has been welcomed with great unease by the producers, who need to see clear the Union's support in this context, so I would like to ask you right now, Commissioner, to comply with what has been announced and tomorrow, 16 September, to present a system for the allocation of emergency aid which does not give rise to unbalanced situations. The European Commission, in my view, should already be seriously considering recourse against Russia to the World Trade Organization, and on the issue of economic resources, the funds should not be confined to the agricultural budget, but should also come from other chapters of the Union budget, bearing in mind that, as we have said, , this is a problem caused by circumstances totally outside the sector.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we believe that sanctions were necessary to stop Russian aggression, without forgetting, of course, the responsibilities of the European Union and the United States of America in the turn taken by the Maidan uprising. But wasn't Russia's response expected? Was! Shouldn't the Commission have immediately had a plan ready to promote at least vulnerable products in new markets, to promote them in the secondary sector or in schools, in hospitals? Where are the new upgraded tools provided for in the just-adopted Common Agricultural Policy? Why is the use of the Crisis Fund delayed if the appropriations are available? Even as if that were not enough, we are cutting all EUR 125 million earmarked for vulnerable agricultural products. The economies of the South will not withstand such a crisis without help. Farmers see their crop rotting, and they will still see it rot because the crisis will last over a year. Transport, to which no one has referred, not only loses a percentage of profit, but risks total extinction. Finally, I would like to stress to the Commissioner that if the allowances are delayed by a year it is possible that there are no more farmers to receive them and that time seems to pass differently from the Commission and differently from farmers.

name: Zbigniew Krzysztof Kuźmiuk (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The effects of the Russian embargo on food from the 28 countries of the European Union are increasingly severe for European farmers, and the European Commission is behaving as if we are dealing with some minor problem. The prices of agricultural products, both plant and animal, in my country, Poland, as a result of this embargo have fallen by an average of 30-40% compared to the previous year, and the European Commission's response is merely to announce the use of a reserve for market distortions. The Russian embargo has caused a genuine crisis on most agricultural markets in those EU countries that were large exporters to this market, while the Commission has decided not to use the CAP crisis reserve.  Please explain why, in the context of the worst agricultural crisis in years, the Commission has not proposed to use this year's CAP crisis reserve for compensation payments. Has Polish Minister of Agriculture requested its use? If so, why has this proposal not been taken into account? When will the funds from the market disruption reserve be unlocked and what was the reason for this blockade?

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: I should like to begin by noting that we do not follow the European Union in this trade war because we have a dual ity of criteria vis-à-vis other regions and other countries, such as Israel, which has recently committed crimes and violated elementary rules of international law. Secondly, I would like to convey to you the deep indignation of Portuguese farmers because Portugal has lived three years of troika intervention, has undergone a profound internal devaluation process with a fall in wages - allegedly to revive the competitiveness of their exports - and this embargo has, of course, caused numerous losses.  Because we also have to go to concrete, to real situations. When a country like Portugal, or any other country, intends to export out of European space - Brazil, Russia, whatever - are months of negotiations, are visits of the health authorities who go to the countries to assess, finally, the conditions of local production, etc., and therefore this embargo has incalculable losses and therefore the question I have to ask is this : what measures, what response can we give to those agents who have worked hard and who now see their expectations completely defrauded?

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. With the Russian ban on the import of food from the European Union, an immediate loss of more than EUR 4.5 million has been caused in Austria alone in the shortest possible time, and the long-term damage to the agricultural economy cannot yet be estimated.  It is therefore also urgent for the European Commission to respond quickly and efficiently to market failures. For the first time since the reform of the common agricultural policy, the new crisis instruments are now being used and emergency measures have also been adopted. However, we have already learned that, for example, support for fruit and vegetables has already been exhausted. However, I see this not only as a lack of money, but in particular a lack of solidarity with our farmers and producers in Europe.  I would therefore like to put two specific questions to the Commission at the same time. Firstly, has the Commission earmarked funds outside the agricultural budget for measures in the European Union in terms of market impact or capacity utilisation? Secondly, is the Commission thinking of preventive measures to prevent crises in the sectors, for example, from arising in the first place? Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work European farmers are not faced with a risk of default, which can be sumbly subsumed under occupational risk. This is not an unexpected but calculable bad weather. This is a political crisis for Europe. Europe's farmers will not be able to cope with this crisis alone. Aid must therefore not, in retrospect, lead to drastic reductions in direct payments.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D). -
text: Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Presidency of the Council of Ministers, ladies and gentlemen, the intervention measures for the milk sector recently adopted to deal with the Russian embargo are obviously welcome, but I fear that they may not be sufficient. There is no doubt that this is a European problem and the repercussion across Europe will soon make it feel with negative effects on the price paid to the producer. If that is the case, the measures adopted so far will not be sufficient. The sector calls for support measures for the promotion and possible exploitation of other markets. There is a need to speed up trade with some potential partners, but this cannot, of course, set any precedent for the negotiations currently underway. I come from a region, the Azores, where milk production accounts for 30 % of national production, and for this reason, and because it is an outermost region, the sector is at serious risk of suffering from this embargo. I would like to appeal to colleagues and colleagues, european policy makers, not to waste this opportunity to question, without prejudice, the end of milk quotas and the consequences that the lack of an effective market regulation mechanism will bring to Europe's milk producers.

name: Bas Belder (ECR). -
text: The ban on imports is hitting our agricultural sector and also the European fisheries sector hard. And which sector is next? The amount of EUR 125 million is not enough. I am asking the Commission to release at least EUR 1 billion, and that amount must not be at the expense of the agricultural budget, i would like to emphasise that. This is, after all, a political crisis.  Under chapter 4 on the budget is money for international political developments. And there are still many unused resources available there. I have tabled an amendment to the Committee on Budgets which I would gladly send you, Commissioner. I hope for your support, ladies and gentlemen! Finally, two short questions: is the Commission capable of excluding the unlawful use of the funds and is the Commission prepared to authorise crisis cartels in order to limit supply on the market? Please provide an update on this.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). -
text: Commissioner, I ask you directly whether, when the European Union authorities took these measures, they knew or not - had they foreseen or not - that there would be countermeasures from Russia? And how did they predict to react to Russia's countermeasures? Secondly, were they aware or not aware that these measures mainly concern and affect the rural economy, i.e. the primary sector? Did they or did they not know that the measures particularly affect Greek producers who are fruit producers? Fruit trees are not like broccoli and cabbages. It's not easy to destroy the tree and replace it with cabbages and broccoli. That's of huge importance. And I go on: what funds does it have and how much does the crisis management fund allocate? And most importantly, in this "cockfight" between Russia and the European Union, that is to say in the context of the Atlantic alliance in particular, who pays the costs of transporting NATO troops to Ukraine?

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I must point out that this is not an agricultural crisis, but a political problem, so I believe that farmers should be compensated for the damage caused by the Russian embargo outside the agricultural budget, which already insufficiently covers all the needs of European farmers.  The measures taken so far by the European Commission do not cover all agricultural products which also account for a significant proportion of exports to Russia such as milk, meat and citrus fruits. So far, I have already called on the European Commission several times to help milk producers who are already in serious crisis, and the conflict with Russia has only added salt to their wound.  For us in Croatia, but also in other Mediterranean countries, an important share of exports to Russia is made up of mandarins that have not been on the list of products for which damages will be compensated, so here I once again publicly call on the European Commission to make accurate calculations taking into account the specifics of the Member States and to provide funds for all farmers who, through no fault of their own , found in a difficult situation.  Agricultural producers need to be provided with new markets and the European Union must find a way to protect its own food production, so caution should be exercised when concluding new trade agreements that could ultimately be unfavourable for European farmers. One of the interesting markets for milk, fruit and vegetables is certainly schools, so the European Commission should increase funding subsidising so-called healthy meals for children in schools. Here again I recall the necessity of changing the criteria in order to enable Croatia, as a new Member State, to participate in these programmes, because the current criteria are discriminatory for us and our children.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the export ban on Russia means a major blow to European agriculture, as last year alone the European Union exported €12 billion worth of agricultural products to Russia. The comparison of the value of exports with the compensation figures clearly shows that European producers will be strongly affected by this embargo. In particular, I point out small producers that are not priced with large ones with almost dumpish prices of their products, and who are often of questionable quality. They tend to adapt to exports to other world markets because they do not have enough resources. And small farms in Croatia account for as much as 90% of the total. Mandarins are just one of the Croatian products that was not on the compensation list, and almost 40% of total production had to go to the Russian market. Apple producers are also severely affected - sanctions have seriously affected Croatia, which is why more adequate solutions must be found.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR). -
text: Madam President! I would actually like to put a question to the Commission in essence. I naturally share the regret expressed here about the fate suffered by the Russian embargo on farmers, who are, through no fault of their own, victims of this Russian embargo, which can go as far as endangering their livelihoods. But my question is this: did the Commission not consider the European Union's and other vulnerabilities when it developed sanctions when it proposed sanctions? Has the Council not considered that these vulnerabilities exist and what impact this will have on European farmers or other economic groups concerned? If this has been taken into account, why has the European Parliament not been informed and has been informed from the outset what compensatory measures are possible to ensure that these burdens are absorbed in solidarity? I have the impression that, at the moment, there is a much more sophisticated attempt to provide compensatory mechanisms in a form of piecemeal work, but that this is not part of a strategy that has really been thought through from the outset, and that would have been necessary.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE). -
text: Madam President, the Russian embargo on European production is having serious effects not only for our farmers and ranchers, with particular impact on more fragile regions such as the Canary Islands, but also on the fisheries and aquaculture sector, which is being seriously affected. I must admit that in these areas I would have liked to have acted with the diligence with which Commissioner Ciolo did so, because we must not forget that exports of fishery products to Russia account for 5% of the total European Union. In fact, Russia is our sixth largest market. That is why, from here, today I would like to draw the Commission's attention to farmers, but also to our fishermen, to take into account and act on the possible consequences of this crisis on markets, as well as to establish the aid that may be necessary for the fisheries and aquaculture sector. I urge the Commission to put in place all the necessary means to assist the sector, including, where appropriate, the temporary change in the quotas allocated annually, as well as the establishment of aid, either in relation to storage — and a clear example of this need we have in the species of marujito, of paramount importance to Galicia — or in the promotion of new markets or extraordinary aid not included in the Maritime and Fisheries Fund. The European Union must act in this sector immediately. Both the agricultural and fisheries sectors are confident.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this was said earlier, the Commission has reacted swiftly and within our budgetary limits in terms of the agricultural budget. This has been done quickly and efficiently, but we know that it is not enough. The first fundamental question that comes to mind is that this is a political crisis derived from a difficult situation, but that its consequences today are being experienced, especially by fruit and vegetable producers, and by milk producers as well. Is it only the agricultural budget that needs to be sought and can we not bring in another one, so as to respond effectively? There is an urgency because the harvest of fruits, especially apples and pears, is now and in a few days.  On the other hand, not all producers in different countries can be penalized because in some countries the rightful holders may not have been properly accounted for. Therefore, the recent suspension of aid of 125 million is probably not the appropriate signal.  There are two key points for me. As a former rapporteur on aid to the poorest, I would like to point out that many European citizens live below the poverty line and that, very clearly, it is very possible - mrs Tiziana Beghin said before me - to buy back production and make it available to food banks, at least for effective distribution.
