It's fundamental. Second point: I turned into a seller of pears and apples in a market in my region and I measured the receptiveness of citizens to consume differently and to help producers. Therefore, could we not take advantage of the opportunity - and I know that this issue will be discussed in this Parliament - to start and reset a new programme, a school-level feeding programme, a food rehabilitation programme that would be fundamental. It is legitimate to conquer other external markets, but domestic demand must also be strengthened.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Madam President, I too would have been happy if the clock had stopped so that I could speak more. Commissioner, you have not convinced us with the answers you have given and you have probably raised greater concerns among farmers in the European South. The damage they've done is enormous! And the sums you have provided for, these EUR 125 million, are crumbs, but even these have not been given. Furthermore, you have not explained to us why the payment of funds from the Reserve Fund is not being promoted. At a time when the European South is impoverished, when our farmers had sought at least one way out, they had sought to get their products out, and they had succeeded, in the Russian markets. Today, therefore, peach producers in Pella, Imathia, those who produce fruit and vegetables in Crete are destroyed. I had therefore asked you a question as early as the beginning of August to answer this question. We have tabled a joint statement, myself and my colleagues from the Five Stars, what measures must be taken to tackle the problem, to save our farmers. You have to have a realistic policy. The South is impoverished and it is not possible for our farmers to suffer, as collateral damage, the consequences of an absurd cold war policy between the European Union and Russia.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE). -
text: Mr President, in good time only to, in fact, to challenge the committee on a privileged opportunity because directly and has to do with a document that was recently distributed at the COM AGRI meeting on the reaction to this Russian embargo and the step in that document can be read in the information note that in the case of reduction of , finally, if direct compensation is decided at national or European level, the reduction of direct payments to farmers may be decided.  What I think is sensible in the event of difficulties with farmers because of measures to combat the embargo is that direct payments could increase these compensations. And I confess that i was in this meeting of the Committee on Agriculture. I have already questioned the Commissioner in writing but, because it is a key instrument to combat the consequences of the embargo - and I understand that, from an external point of view, there has to be a consequence for Russia for what is happening in Ukraine - but because these consequences have a direct financial impact on farmers in the compensation that can be attributed to farmers to tackle the problem of the embargo It would be justified, it seems to me, that one thing would not imply the exclusion of the other, that is, by deciding the commission direct compensation, such compensation should not reduce direct payments to farmers. And deep down, that's the clarification I'd like to get from the Commissioner.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: We are talking at the moment about an issue that we have only seen at the beginning, we do not know what the medium or long-term course of this is. However, we know firmly – and this may be a lesson – that the Russian market is to be regarded as uncertain in the long term. European sanctions, by the way, were ones that did not hurt the people of everyday life. Russian oligarchs, Russian financial and military industry groups were hit. I think that was a smart move. At the same time, the embargo imposed by Putin hurts not only European agricultural producers, but also the Russian people. It is therefore safe to point out that Vladimir Putin has committed an immeasurable crime in this matter. At the same time, individual European producers are hurting in different ways by this embargo. Perhaps best for Polish apple producers, but also for Scottish farmers, yes for Scottish farmers. However, food is not for destroying, it is not for cleaning, nor is it even for stored on expensive money. It's for us to eat! Europe's response to this Russian embargo must be to eat our own food. There's a lot of hungry people here. My colleague Tarabella and others have made it very clear that young people, children, the elderly, the socially disadvantaged can eat this surplus very, very quickly. Let us not underestimate the value of the internal market of 500 million. My fellow Members, we are talking about a problem of 10 euros per European citizen per person. Let no one tell me that we cannot give our children ten euros more food. But if this idea is such a difficult birth, then I will say, at worst, let us take it to the starving Ukrainians, there are many in eastern Ukraine!

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has engaged in an arm-wrestle with Russia, which has disastrous consequences for our farmers: these are the collateral effects of a diplomatic crisis. Without questioning the action that is being taken, I believe it is our duty to support them. Although the European Commission reacted quickly by making available an envelope of EUR 125 million for fruit and vegetables, this is clearly insufficient. The envelope has already been exceeded. I would also like to start some ideas. The price of withdrawing products is far too low and does not cover the cost of production in many countries. This is the case in France. This measure is unusable for some Member States. What does the European Commission intend to do about this?  With regard to promotional measures, it is not acceptable for them to be co-financed by producers. Asking producers for a euro so that the Commission can put one is unjustifiable and is absolutely not understood by producers. Especially since I remind you that this is not a market crisis, nor a health crisis, but rather a diplomatic crisis. Is the European Commission also considering the possibility of de minimis de minimis removal? Indeed, these ceilings have been reached in recent years by many crises faced by companies.  Some have talked about aid to the needy, the distribution of fruits and vegetables at recess... Commissioner, your proposal to merge the two milk and fruit and vegetable schemes is just a false good idea. I'm ready to talk to you about it again.  Finally, the actions that are now proposed are emergency actions for the direct needs of the market but this is only the tip of the iceberg. Producers will need long-term actions, including to win back lost markets. Are there any thoughts in that direction?

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Russian crisis is threatening the European agri-food sector dramatically. The numbers of EU countries' exports to Russia are impressive, but equally impressive are the negative effects of this embargo, both in terms of the losses already suffered by the sector and in terms of the closure of the growth prospects so necessary for the revival of the agri-food sector.  It is therefore clear that there is an urgent need to identify urgent incentive measures, particularly in the fruit and vegetable, dairy and meat sectors, so that companies in the sector can recover from the effects of an all-political crisis and help to identify other markets for outlets, just as action should be taken to change rapidly the way in which the aid already allocated is applied and allocated between the various countries. I believe that we must work to provide for targeted compensation, just as, having verified the budgetary resources available by the European Commission, I hope that extraordinary measures will be taken, as well as measures to bring forward the payment to farmers of CAP funds, as already suggested by the Minister of Agriculture Maurizio Martina. What Commissioner Cioloș said is certainly to be welcomed, but it is not enough. What I am asking, however, is the timeliness of the European Union's action. European farmers cannot wait, not least because, as they say in my part of the world, while the doctor is studying, the patient is in danger of dying.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The effects of the embargo are very serious for agriculture throughout the European Union, but they are particularly acute for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, especially Polish. It is clear that the proposed amounts of support are far from sufficient, and I am pleased with the Commissioner's announcement on the next steps in this area.  In the last week, understandably, we have paid the most attention to the issue of fruit and vegetables, but we must bear in mind the losses of milk and meat producers. I appeal not only to the European Commission, but also to the Member States that have blocked the change, the correction of the fat ratio, so that, in the event of a drastic fall in milk prices, milk producers should not be penalisation for exceeding production quotas. I also consider the application of up to half the compensation to producers not affiliated to producer groups to be downright discriminatory. Of course, prefering to create producer groups, supporting the creation of producer groups is a good thing, whereas punishing this embargo crisis is absolutely wrong.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I believe, like many colleagues, that it was necessary to act quickly, in a concerted and supportive manner at European level and I would like to thank you for that.  It was the very future of a number of farms, including small farms, that was at stake. We have been able to do this, I recall, through the market management and support tools that we have strongly defended to maintain in the CAP. But the financial assistance available must be provided to the farmers most affected by this crisis. Its management must be as efficient and transparent as possible. A suspension of some of that support was decided, I remind you, last week because of some abuses. This situation needs to be corrected as soon as possible by focusing more on the support provided and making it as effective as possible. Finally, I would like to tell you that there will probably be other products for which Europe's support will be needed. I am thinking in particular of live meat and live beef, which were exported to Russia and are interrupted today. I also think that we will have to work on the issue of humanitarian aid, as many colleagues have pointed out. This will require additional funding. And I am thinking of the introduction of taxation on financial transactions, which is becoming an emergency.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE). -
text: I would like to thank the Commissioner for what he has said, but a great deal has happened in the Netherlands. The plane crash on Thursday 17 July with MH17 brought the war in Ukraine for the Netherlands close. The Netherlands has been deeply affected by this terrible event. Shortly thereafter, we were hit by the Russian trade boycott, which got many of our farmers, gardeners and fishermen into trouble. Last week, the Russian government again announced sanctions against Western countries, which will once again hit Europe hard. Because the Russian sanctions are a direct response to the economic punitive measures of the west, the creation of support among the European population is of great importance. Because only through political and economic pressure can we hope for peace and stability. I therefore call on the Commissioner to explicitly ask tomorrow to clearly support the resolution proposed for more money. I am not simply advocating this, because in the Netherlands alone we need more than EUR 1 billion. Finally, the unlawful use should be excluded. When it comes to the crisis cartel - because our Secretary of State in the Netherlands is quite critical of you - this could clearly provide quick solutions. Because there is a feeling that this is taking far too long in Europe and that our farmers and gardeners are left with the consequences.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE). -
text: Commissioner, congratulations on the way you have handled the difficult problem with Russia, but I would like to raise the issue of the real impact of the embargo imposed by Russia on food in the European Union, and in this context, obviously the question of compensation and how it will be calculated and awarded must be discussed. It is not only by the impossibility of delivering these goods to Russia that losses have been made, but also by the cancellation of a large number of orders on the intra-Community market. In practice, The European food refused by Russia, which remained in Europe, saturated domestic markets and made it impossible to conduct exchanges routinely in previous years. For example, a Romanian producer that traditionally sold on the German market finds an oversaturated market this year, just like other European markets. As a result, huge stocks have been collected in the warehouses, and the merchandise is breaking down. Basically, Romanian producers have so far lost half the crop. If other countries lost the Russian market, Romania lost the markets on which food destined for Russia was redirected. We can't think simplistic. We have to accept that all states have lost because the markets have been upset. Therefore, any aid granted must take into account this aspect of the crisis: the blocking of intra-Community agricultural and food trade and not just actual sales to Russia. That is why, Commissioner, I am asking for a point of view on this issue.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI). -
text: Madam President, thank you for giving me the floor despite my delay. It is clear, Madam President, Commissioner, that we shot ourselves in the foot and fell into the trap of sanctions.  The European Union is offering only 125 million euros to the market gardening sector, while the Russian embargo affects all agricultural production. Your action is catastrophic for us in France. Here are some figures: - 12% for fruits, - 13% on vegetables, - 20% on apples, pears, melons, peaches.  The ton of milk powder increased from 2,900 to 2,300 euros. A ton of butter from 3,500 to 3,000 euros. I cannot forget our Dutch friends who, with their 250,000 tonnes of Edam, also export to Russia. Finally, the pig farmers here, according to the assessments of the regional pig committee of Brittany, have already lost 15 euros per pig, or 70,000 euros for the average breeder. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the European Commission and the Council, it is high time to put an end to this irresponsible policy of the European Union. France is Russia's third largest supplier of agri-food products, worth one billion euros per year. I have only one piece of advice for you tonight: change your policy! Think of our farmers, lift the embargo!

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D). -
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for trying to find quick solutions in the crisis that has createded. But the European Union has not found the effective remedy for treating the effects of the embargo.  For small countries such as Bulgaria, the direct and indirect losses are huge. Bankruptcies knock on the doors of many farmers. Today, we cannot answer them either about the terms of the embargo or whether there will be a policy change or whether the CAP compensation budget will last and how long.  You say there will be new measures. Listen to this time and the Bulgarian farmers, because what you offer does not take into account the specifics in the Member States. Benefits should be affordable and fast, but bureaucracy is killing them. Promises of new markets are still only promises and have not replaced Russian ones. Joint programmes with Russia co-financed by the European Union must also be compensated, because otherwise the losses will be huge. The spiral of economic sanctions is endless, but so far it has not been a solution to any problem.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE). -
text: Madam President, you had quick reflexes when you took action last August. But the crisis didn't start with the embargo on Russia. The crisis began with the war situation in Ukraine. That is why many times, and especially the countries of South-Eastern Europe, have faced enormous problems. Every country has its own history. For example, for Greece the impact is focused on the fruit and vegetable sector. 65% of greece's fruit and vegetable exports go to Russia. For Greece it is impossible to approach the markets in Russia and, above all, in Southern Russia. They need to travel 1,500 kilometers to get through Belarus. So costs rise and product prices are squeezed. For example, for peaches, which have been most affected by any other product in our country, prices have fallen from 70 and 80 cents to 15 and 20 cents. The damage that will follow concerns other products: kiwis, citrus fruits, pears, tomatoes, cucumbers, a whole host of products produced mainly in the European South. Commissioner, what we would like and what we are asking for is for immediate new measures to be taken. And in these immediate new measures there should be no distinction between individual producers and producers who are organised. We call for you to activate all the funds provided for in EU regulations to support producers throughout Europe and especially in Southern Europe.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the last meeting of the Council of Ministers showed that the measures set by the Commission are not sufficient by either means or the extent. In addition, measures to help producers of certain types of fruit and vegetables worth €125 million have been suspended due to too many requests. In situations like this, two things are crucial: elaborate measures and quick reaction.  It is in our common interest that we all resolve the situation as soon as possible and as quickly as possible, but I emphasize, taking into account each other's specificities. Croatia exports 1.3% of agri-food products to the Russian market. We are particularly concerned about fruit exports, notably mandarins, which have grown many times in the past few years. Nevertheless, citrus fruits are not included in the Commission scheme so far.  In my view, it is necessary to react as soon as possible to the specific requirements of all Member States due to the existence of businessmen, which depends on the timely response, but also because of the fact that market distortions in one Member State spill over to others, thereby increasing their consequences.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR). -
text: Madam President, Russia's response to the sanctions comes in the form of this ban which is very painful for European food producers. Many of them are likely to ask the question: "Did the European Union need an engagement around Ukraine that is costing us quite a bit together now?" I believe so, because I think the right thing to do in spite of the consequences.  I welcome the Commission's package of intervention measures in the fruit and vegetables sector and believe that we must not allow this burden to fall solely on the backs of European producers. I also call on the Commission to include mandarins in the package, as Croatian mandarin producers will be particularly affected by this ban.  Namely, 50% of croatian mandarin exports go to the Russian market, which means that under the current circumstances Croatian producers will lose more than 10 million euros. Such a loss can leave devastating consequences on the small country's agriculture sector such as Croatia.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, I believe that the debate raised by this question is as necessary as the sanctions being imposed on Russia for its action in the Ukraine conflict. I hope that the path of dialogue— clearer today than in August — will bear fruit; meanwhile, producers and transformers of agricultural and fishery products cannot be the heathens of these measures. I would particularly like to stress the fisheries sector. Russia imported fresh or processed fishery products from Europe worth 115 million euros. I would like to know whether, in fact, as the Commissioner announced on her blog, resources from the Maritime and Fisheries Fund will be mobilizing without further formality to compensate for these losses; whether some of the products that cannot be stored in the medium term can be systematically devoted to alleviating the needs of The Europeans most affected by the crisis; and finally, how the proposal on uns used quotas will be finally finally final in order to improve income expectations for the sector in 2015.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, the Scottish whisky exports to Russia do not seem, on the face of it, very much at GBP 25 million. However, another GBP 200 million worth of Scottish whisky gets to Russia via Germany, Latvia and Estonia. It is a direct carousel. If there is any compensation going begging, Commissioner, it ought to go to the producers of Scottish whisky in Scotland and not to those who simply trade it on. As you know, the UK is a very substantial net contributor to the common agricultural policy, and some of that money coming back to Scotland would be very useful. Scotland is an important part of the United Kingdom. There are 143 million people living in Russia. They are not going to stop eating. Food originally produced in the European Union will find its way there somehow. I urge the Commission not to obstruct these rather unofficial processes.

name: Diane Dodds (NI). -
text: Madam President, in Northern Ireland the greatest impact of the Russian import ban is on the dairy sector. I am therefore calling on the Commission to review the prices set for intervention and to reintroduce export refunds as a priority. Introducing these measures would protect the industry and stabilise markets across the EU. I would also call on the Commission to ensure that these safety-net tools and compensation are delivered quickly, effectively and fairly, and not just to Member States which border Russia. A final word for the Commissioner: please do not give in to those Member States which have broken the rules and over-produced milk which they will be releasing into a market which is already experiencing a downward spiral in prices, thereby penalising farmers like those in Northern Ireland who have kept to the rules.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE). -
text: There is a military operation in Ukraine - a political conflict, innocent people are dying in Ukraine, people who have driven innocents in a passenger plane have died, and the next victims are European farmers who are losing the market. The key solution to this conflict and this crisis is to sit diplomacy at the table and to end this military conflict as soon as possible and to find a political solution.  As far as the measures in the field of agriculture are concerned, I welcome the measures it has prepared for the Commission, I congratulate Commissioner Cioloş and his team on these measures and to continue to monitor, on a weekly basis, what is happening in these markets and also to act in a similar way to what they have done so far.  I very much support that the measures go in the direction of stimulating the search for new markets and not in order not to destroy products, but rather to give these products, as envisaged, to those who need these foods. I therefore welcome the measures, keep on going, and the policy should find a political solution as soon as possible to end the military conflict.

name: José Blanco López (S&D). -
text: Madam President, there is no doubt that I do not question the embargo on Russia, the sanctions on Russia, but there is no doubt that the european Commission's response is neither effective nor sufficient for sectors which, in some territories, are strategic sectors because of the weight they have: for example, the dairy sector or the fisheries sector in the region of which I am natural Galicia. It is therefore necessary to demand greater resources from the European Union. We are talking about exports of many entities in the face of budgeted resources by the Union, rather insufficient. Therefore, more resources are needed. What is happening is the result of a decision of the European Union and should therefore not fall on the common agricultural policy. Extraordinary resources must be allocated and should be done more quickly and more efficiently.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, indeed, there are many questions. I will try to answer as many of them as possible in a synthetic way. First of all, some of you , and only some, fortunately - question the usefulness of sanctions and question whether the Commission has foreseen the consequences of the decisions it has taken.  I just want to point out - but you know - that it is not the Commission that has taken the sanctions against Russia, it is the European Union. And it is the Council that has clearly decided by a very large political majority. So I cannot comment further on this decision that was made and that was taken politically. What we have done about the impact of the Russian embargo is also to assume our responsibility as the European Union towards the agricultural sector.  Some of you say that the Commission did not react quickly enough. The embargo was decided on 7 August and on 11 August, we have already launched the first measure for the "peaches and nectarines" sector, which was already affected, as some of you have said, even before the Russian embargo, but whose situation has been aggravated by the latter. So, after only a few days, we took the first step, ten days after the big package for fruits and vegetables and another ten days later, again in August, the measures for the dairy sector. I recall what I said in my introduction, it was the area that was most affected. Why have we only targeted certain fruits and vegetables and not all? We targeted anything that fit into the "seasonal products" category. I would remind you that everything we put on the list of products to be addressed was agreed with the Member States. Indeed, in mid-August, we held the first meeting with the experts of the Member States and it was only after these types of meetings with the Member States that we decided what the list was. I made it clear at the time we took these first steps that, if necessary, further action would follow. So citrus fruits, including mandarins, will follow on this list. There will also be more apples, pears and other seasonal products that will be integrated into what the Commission will propose. Therefore, we took into account the urgency and took into account, in terms of the envelope, everything we felt was necessary. You withheld EUR 125 million because that was the figure that was the most widely reported in the press. But before mobilising the 125 million euros for fruits and vegetables, we had already mobilised 30 million euros for peaches and nectarines, which were therefore available to producers as of 11 August.  In addition, measures for the dairy sector, for private storage for which we have estimated the needs at around 30 million euros. But private storage for cheese, butter and powdered milk is always open. We have no limits here, because that is the principle of this measure. We estimate the needs, but when the private storage measure is open for a certain period of time, we take into account everything the producer decides to store and not sell. The producer makes the decision to store if he considers the market price to be too low.  Some here have said that the measures are insufficient for the dairy sector. We have mobilized all the measures that we had in the safety nets that are available to producers. They decide whether or not to use them as the market evolves.  I conclude that the Commission acted quickly, as quickly as possible, that it acted in a proportionate manner, since the amount we have proposed, for example, for fruits and vegetables, is EUR 125 million plus EUR 30 million for peaches and nectarines. I would remind you that it is the estimate of the value of what we had exported to Russia and that had to be withdrawn. When we take that production out of the market, when we do not use that production in the industry, we cover the cost of that withdrawal. Again, I would point out that we have mainly insisted, in withdrawal from the market, on free distribution. Some of you have come up with different ideas on what should be done at European level for this free distribution for the poorest people. Producers, especially producers' organizations, are free to use for free distribution the amount they want from all the products they withdraw. For all withdrawn products that are distributed free of charge, the financial compensation provided by the regulation is 100% European funding. It's only for products that are removed and are dedicated to composting or biodegradation that co-financing is required from producers.  Therefore, we have clearly encouraged free distribution and the Member States have full freedom in this area, since that is what the regulation of the legislator, namely the Council and Parliament, provides for. It is the Member States that are implementing the programme of free distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools and Member States therefore have the freedom to use all the margins they have at their disposal to increase the amount of free distribution. From this point of view, we have also done everything possible to ensure that the products that are withdrawn can be distributed free of charge. It was an emergency and we acted quickly and proportionately. In terms of budget allocations, as I said, we are preparing for the next few days - I hope to be able to announce this week - a new package of measures for fruits and vegetables, which will take into account a new substantial envelope calculated on the basis of the realities on the ground. Tomorrow we will hold another meeting with the Member States where we will discuss these proposals. We will then announce the new package of measures that will include other seasonal products, some of which you have mentioned.  What will be done after that if the embargo continues? One way or another, beyond the urgent steps we have taken, we must also consider further diversifying our markets. But the most important thing we can do is encourage the producers, because they decide where they will sell - you can't force them to sell in one place and not sell in another. What we can do is provide them with the means to look for new markets.  We are looking at promotional and communication actions, as well as commercial diplomacy. The current Commission will do everything in its power until the end of its mandate to try to open up other markets whose access is now limited for exports of European products for plant health reasons. I myself will take the necessary steps. Commissioner Karel De Gucht, here, has already begun these steps and I know that he will continue. We will conduct these measures in parallel.  Some of you have said that perhaps we should increase consumption in the domestic market. We have means for promotion and communication in the internal market as well. I would remind you that Parliament and the Council recently adopted a regulation in June; it was in fact the mandate of the previous Parliament, which adopted a new European regulation for the promotion of agri-food products. We will thereby increase the budgetary envelope for promotion between 2014 and 2020, both in the internal and external markets.  So that's what we're looking at for the future. First, make sure that for products that cannot be resold, including perishable products, we have immediate solutions. And for next year, farmers will know what the market situation is and they will make decisions about production, production type, market targeting based on the situation of the embargo - depending on whether it continues or not. But in terms of our exports to Russia, I think we have the means to redirect that production as we go along to other markets. With regard to the budget, many of you have said that the budget is not enough and that the Commission needs to put more money into it. It has even been suggested that we should provide not a few hundred million euros but a billion euros. But we will put two billion euros, three billion euros if the Member States give this money to the Commission. I would remind you that the Commission, on the other hand, has no money. It manages a budget decided by legislators. If, in the 2014-2020 budget outlook, the decision was to reduce the budget and, in particular, to reduce the Commission's margin of payment, it cannot go beyond that. In recent weeks, the Commission has tried to manage the emergency by allocating the necessary money. Just because we didn't have enough money doesn't mean we've put a total of 180 million euros so far. That is because, according to our estimates with the Member States, that is the amount we have deemed necessary. But we have always said that we are prepared to plan for more. We'll do it in the next few days. But for compensation, it will clearly be necessary to go beyond the margins available to the Commission in the budget and mobilize the crisis reserve. Why have we not mobilized the crisis reserve so far? Because it was not necessary as long as we had margins in the budget that we decided to use. This is the principle of what is called sound management, the efficient management of the budget. We first use the margins and then, if necessary, we mobilize the crisis reserve. I believe, indeed, that we will need to mobilise it in order, in particular, to cover compensatory measures which we, the current Commission or the next Commission, need to discuss. In any case, we take responsibility. It is for this reason that the crisis reserve has not been mobilised, but there is nothing to prevent it from being mobilised and, if necessary, it goes without saying that we will do so. You say that we need fairer distribution criteria. We have very clear criteria and, with the proposals we will make in the coming days for the fruit and vegetable sector, they will be even clearer to avoid abuses and notifications that are not tenable given the realities on the ground. Some of you have talked about the indirect impact of this Russian embargo. Thus, the affected states are not only those that export to Russia, notably the Baltic countries, Finland, Poland, but also Spain, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, which are also affected both directly and indirectly. We take this indirect impact into account by proposing market measures for all Member States and not just for the Member States affected. But, of course, we have done it in a proportionate way. With regard to the fisheries sector, some of you have raised this issue, I can tell you from my colleague, Maria Damanaki, that she has already started discussions with the Member States and the fisheries sector. Evaluations are underway to see what types of measures we will need to mobilize. But clearly, we cannot compare the impact on the agricultural sector and the fishing sector. In agriculture, the impact on our exports was in the order of billions of euros, whereas for the fishing sector it was - I am not mistaken - in the order of eur 100 million. If this is necessary for the fishing sector, we will take action, but of course we have targeted the most important priority, namely the agricultural sector. Some of you have called for the lifting of sanctions on milk quotas. In my opinion, it would be totally counterproductive: lifting the sanctions on milk and having even more milk on the market when we already have a surplus as a result of this Russian embargo. Therefore, I do not think at all that, in the current situation, the right thing to do is to lift the quota sanctions and turn on the tap for production.  I will stop there because I feel like I have answered all the questions. There were more specific issues that I am willing to discuss with those of you who would be interested, including those, more technical, on the withdrawal price, on co-financing, etc.  I thank you very much for your support of the commission's actions and I hope to be able to count on the same support in the future.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – One good news we have heard from the Commission tonight is that support for EU farmers affected by the Russian embargo will be renewed, and seasonal fruit and vegetable growers can expect support again this year. Although the Commission has reacted effectively by adopting measures for these sectors, the meat and milk sectors are equally affected by the Russian embargo. The situation of farmers in some EU Member States is further aggravated by the problem of swine fever, which the Commission has so far been prepared to pay due attention and support to the crisis caused by E. coli, when the large EU Member States affected by it were affected. The Russian embargo and the recent difficulties faced within the EU itself are a test that will show how the EU adheres to the principle of solidarity vis-à-vis its Member States. The Russian embargo is a serious problem for all EU countries and I hope that Europe will stand up to it in solidarity and unity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – For Lithuania and other Baltic countries, the Russian embargo strikes the strongest. And here we need to talk not only about business losses. The important and social consequences that the most sensitive social groups in our countries will undoubtedly have to suffer through declining incomes or even job losses. I therefore call on the Commission to assess the need for additional support for countries whose labour markets will suffer under the Russian embargo. In this context, I would suggest that consideration be given to the possibility of providing support from the European Globalisation Fund so that this fund can be used more expeditiously and effectively to help workers who may be made redundant in the future from companies affected by Russian sanctions. I would also like to call on the Commission to declare the Baltic states an area of exceptional needs and to set up a special fund for these countries to support and compensate for the losses of the Baltic farmers. Given the challenges already faced by farmers in the Baltic states due to the smallest direct payments still received throughout the European Union and the disproportionate impact of the Ban on Russian imports, it is clear that the agricultural sector in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania needs special EU support. Also, it must not be forgotten that russia's actions in the face of the crisis are equally important and a long-term solution to the problem is also needed. EU aid is also needed to help farmers reorient to other agricultural sectors and find alternative markets for production.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: With the Russian embargo, food imports from the United States, The European Union, Canada, Australia and Norway were blocked for 12 months. The risk is to bring our sectors already affected by the crisis to their knees to their knees. The value of the agri-food products affected by the embargo is estimated by the European Commission at 5 billion Euros, affecting the income of 9 million Europeans. These figures are absolutely optimistic because many factors such as triangulation trade, long-term market loss are not taken into account and imbalances in the internal market are not taken into account. The aid allocated will therefore not be sufficient. The European Union must provide for a more careful distribution of resources and must work to build a true harmonised European single market, capable of absorbing shocks and emergencies, managing internal trade flows in a forward-looking way.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – I appreciate the European Commission's efforts to compensate farmers who have suffered. As it stands, however, this is not enough. The funds released so far are already oversubscribed and the payment of the funds has been suspended. Additional EU funds need to be raised. All available Union funds should be used to compensate producers. I support parliament's Committee on Agriculture's efforts to realrate, in addition to agricultural funds, money from the reserve for this year's and next year's EU budgets to help European farmers. Russian sanctions imposed solely for foreign policy reasons are mostly imposed by our masters. The EU has a duty to show solidarity with them. This is why, in addition to agricultural resources, EU funds need to be found to compensate producers. However, the resources of the Agricultural Crisis Fund will only be used as a last end once all other options have been exhausted. Direct aid shall not be reduced. In order to help producers, during the negotiation of the EU budget for 2015, my colleague Tamás Deutsch and I initiated a significant increase in the framework of the school fruit scheme. This could be a good tool for selling some of the surplus produce due to Russian sanctions on fruit producers.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. – European farmers are currently experiencing difficult times because of Russia's decision to ban imports of agricultural products from the European Union. For example, the purchase price of milk in Latvia has fallen by 30% or 40% in a few weeks and is now below 19 cents per litre. Milk processing companies are also suffering significant losses as a result of the closure of the Russian market. Currently, Latvian farmers have met milk quotas by 99.1%. A cow is not a machine that can be turned off. It continues to produce milk. I therefore believe that the EU institutions should decide not to impose fines for exceeding the quota in the remainder of the months until the quota is abolished in 2015. Such a decision would help to maintain many dairy farms in Central and Eastern Europe. Today, however, under the embargo, it is not just an economic decision, it requires political will. I am interested in the European Commission's view on whether fines could be abolished for countries that have exceeded milk quotas and what aid would be available to milk producers (i.e. farmers), because the measures provided for in the CAP are limited to milk processing.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. Russia accounts for around 10% of the European Union's agricultural exports, worth EUR 12 billion per year, and has banned the import of a number of agri-food products for more than a month now. We would like to reassure our producers by asking the European Commission what measures it intends to take both, in the short term, to cushion the damage to the European agricultural sector and, in a longer term, to resolve this situation so that it is not the producers and small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector who suffer. It seems, in fact, that Russia is organising itself, both by increasing its domestic production and by finding alternative trading partners, so that it no longer has to depend on European imports: it becomes necessary to find a solution that will allow us to pursue our foreign policy without damaging our trade policy.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, it is unacceptable to place all producers under a common denominator in competition for the infinitely insufficient compensation of EUR 125 million, which was exhausted in less than ten days. Producers from the new Member States are disadvantaged and at risk of severe social consequences, in competition with goods from older Member States which are also subject to higher agricultural subsidies. I call on Commissioner Ciološ to pay particular attention to the fact that there have been a number of devastating floods in Bulgaria this year, which further bring severe consequences for agricultural production in regions where it is a major livelihood. As a result of these and the subsequent weaker harvest, the Bulgarian agricultural market is under enormous pressure from agricultural production from other Member States. I would also like to express disapproval of discrimination against independent producers for which the subsidy is less than those of members of branch organisations. The union's new agricultural entrepreneurs have been hit again by this measure. I call on the European Commission to take these factors into account when shaping its next proposals and delegated regulations. Thank you, Mr. Chairman!

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I appreciate the Commission's rapid response to the situation in the agricultural sector following the introduction of an embargo on imports into Russia of agricultural products, in particular in the field of fruit and vegetables and dairy products. Specific measures are aimed at mitigating the impact on the internal market, but at the same time they are only temporary measures. However, overpressure in the internal market may also mean a volatility of the internal market by increasing secondary imports. Price dumping should be avoided and the quality of products ensured in order to protect consumers. It is necessary to continue to closely monitor the development of the situation and to focus compensation in a targeted and effective manner, taking into account the medium and long-term outlook.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE) . -
text: First of all, I would like to commend the Commission for reacting very quickly to the new economic situation and for pledging help to those affected. Now, however, it is important to provide fast, unbureaucratic and targeted aid to small and medium-sized enterprises, especially outside industrial centres. These companies are hit hardest by the sanctions. In order to secure business locations and jobs, we must provide targeted assistance!

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on trade with the Euromed countries (2014/2836(RSP)).

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Europe’s southern neighbourhood has gone through unprecedented change since 2011 and, in this context, trade and investment must play a role as a factor of stability: a factor of stability in your relations with the southern Mediterranean region. We are currently focusing on three trade objectives vis-à-vis the southern Mediterranean region. The first one is the deepening of EU trade relations with some of these partners on the basis of a differentiated approach. In December 2011 the Council adopted negotiating directives for deep and comprehensive free trade areas (DCFTAs) with Egypt, Jordan, Morocco and Tunisia. The main objective of these agreements will be the progressive integration of the economies of these partners into the EU single market. These agreements will be comprehensive and will cover regulatory areas of mutual interest such as trade facilitation, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, public procurement and competition policy. They will also include investment protection and further liberalisation of goods, services and establishments, as appropriate. Negotiations on a DCFTA were launched with Morocco in March 2013 and are progressing apace. The preparatory process for the negotiations with Jordan and Tunisia is very advanced, and negotiations could be launched as soon as the preparatory process is completed. The immediate priority for countries where a DCFTA is not immediately possible – such as Libya, Lebanon or Algeria – is their accession to the World Trade Organisation, and contacts continue in this respect. We also need to define the most appropriate trade framework for our relations with Libya in due course. The second focus is support for south-south regional integration. The level of intra-regional trade in the southern Mediterranean is still lower than anywhere else in the world. An integrated Mediterranean market will be much more attractive to investors. We continue to support efforts to reinforce the Agadir Agreement between Egypt, Jordan, Morocco and Tunisia and to extend it to other regulatory areas: to trade and services, investments or public procurement. This also includes providing financial assistance and expertise. The ongoing revision of pan-Euromed rules of origin should be accelerated. This is not an easy task, given the diverging views of the partners participating in this process. The third key element is the regional Euro-Mediterranean trade partnership, which will be revitalised at the upcoming 10th Union for the Mediterranean Trade Ministerial Meeting on 30 September. This is an important meeting, since it will be the first in four years. The Commission is doing its utmost to keep the trade relationship with the EU’s Mediterranean neighbours up to date and to sustain long-term peace and stability in the region. We count on Parliament’s continued dedication to this shared goal.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, I thank you for your presentation on the current state and prospects for trade with Euromed countries. It seems to me that today the balance sheet is as follows - and you have just traced it: trade between the European Union and the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean still offers promising prospects, but there is still a long way to go so that partnerships do not remain variable geometry.  I would like to highlight three things: first, there is a need to continue work towards free trade agreements and in particular by removing non-tariff barriers. The elimination of non-tariff and technical barriers must be done in partnership and with the full involvement and ownership of our partner countries. In this regard, and as you have just pointed out, the partnership with the southern Mediterranean must be based on a strong dynamic of regional integration. Today, however, trade between the countries of the southern Mediterranean remains very low.  The second element is that in order to strengthen trade with partner countries in the Mediterranean, it is crucial to remain pragmatic, to work directly with and for those who carry out trade. Two examples: putting our visa policy at the service of economic policy, i.e. facilitating visa procedures for the corporate world, as with the mobility partnership agreement signed with Morocco in June 2013. The second idea is to further encourage the networking of companies on both sides of the Mediterranean Sea, notably through the creation of bilateral chambers of commerce that can organise joint forums or training. Finally, deepening trade relations and free trade agreements are not an end in themselves. Trade is not the only key to development, but it remains an instrument that can enable these countries to fully integrate into an open global economy.  We must therefore ensure that the development of businesses and trade also promotes the strengthening of states and administrative structures, because we cannot lose sight of the political and social instability in these regions.  So yes to trade in the service of peace and stability.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, Mr. De Gucht, in your presentation, you did not mention the partnership between Europe and Israel. However, I think it is important to be able to recall certain principles in this trade exchange with Israel, particularly the principle of the illegality of the occupation of territories in the West Bank.  To do that, we do have the ability to do two things with trade instruments. The first is, of course, to encourage the Member States which have now taken steps in relation to these products from the occupied territories, i.e. to be able to guarantee the labeling of these products. It is true that this exists today voluntarily in the United Kingdom and also in Belgium. But we hope that at European level we can activate binding measures on the labeling of products from the occupied territories that are illegal products. This would allow European consumers to make the right choices in terms of consumption, it would allow for a change in habits and economic pressure in relation to the unfair situation as it is experienced today.  With regard to the other countries - you mentioned Morocco and Tunisia - I think it is also important to recall a number of principles. The first is that these are countries in democratic transition - I am talking about Tunisia - and it is important to involve civil society in these free trade agreements. It is also important to include social clauses and environmental clauses that are also binding in trade agreements.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask my fellow Member if he agrees that, a half-hour ago, in relation to Russia, Parliament found that Russia had committed aggression against another country and should therefore be subject to sanctions from the European Union. So do you agree – it is very difficult to talk, because here many people are using the chamber as a café again and speaking out loud, but I am trying to over-shout at them – whether we can apply double standards or say that aggression against Gaza can be used... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Maria Arena (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. I ask that there be traceability of the products, it would allow us to make choices in relation to our consumption. If there is no traceability, it is impossible to know where these products come from today and I do not advocate a boycott of all Israeli and Palestinian products, but I would argue that we can find out if these products are made illegally, namely in occupied territories.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the European Union's economic relations with the Mediterranean countries must be based on the principles of mutual benefit and must not be heterogeneous. The creation of a free economic Euro-Mediterranean zone must not create problems for countries facing economic problems, such as the countries of the South, countries affected by mercelial austerity, by the Memorandums. This also applies to Greece and Italy, all the more so now that, as we have seen, the agricultural economy of Greece and the other countries of the South is being affected by the Russian embargo. Also some Mediterranean countries should not have an á la carte policy. This applies to Turkey, which, while it has invaded Cyprus and occupied a large part of the island, nevertheless does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, and nevertheless requires its products to circulate freely and without hindrance in the European Union.  We must also, Mr President, tackle the issue of illegal immigration flows ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, trade is an essential part of our common foreign policy and it should be a more integral part. Its political significance was underlined by the responses to the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. Last summer a wake-up call was given, for those who still needed one, as to the importance of a strong Europe in today’s world. We have a lot to win by expanding the scope of existing agreements in the Euromed region. A few years after courageous people – many of them young – defied repression in calling for democracy, rights and opportunities, not enough positive change has been realised. Sadly, the countries in North Africa and the Middle East face major threats of instability. Still, we must continue with an ambitious trade agenda. It should be at the heart of finally giving meaning to the notion of more for more: more market access, with more reforms towards human rights and democracy. We must be firm, including with Israel, on existing conditionalities, and we must see trade as a means towards more opportunities and rights, towards the prevention of corruption, the more equal distribution of wealth and the empowerment of individuals – the latter especially in combination with education, which should be used to tackle the massive youth unemployment. Increasing opportunities may also help to prevent radicalisation, although clearly it is not the only solution. Certainly it can help curb migration. This is not just a matter of exports and innovations. We should look at ourselves, and at the negative impact that agricultural subsidies have on the opportunities for farmers in the Euromed region, hampering growth there. The EU should also play an active coordinating role, so as to avoid duplication of activities on the ground, and it should support regional integration, which would greatly help economic growth in the Euromed region.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, what you call the neighbourhood with the countries of the southern Mediterranean, some of which seek the paths of justice and freedom, I believe calls for a new type of cooperation with them: cooperation and not competition. It is therefore necessary to change their approach to these countries, which must not constitute new areas of economic expansion, nor an industrial backyard to exploit cheap labour, nor a buffer migration zone of which they would be the guardians on our behalf. On the contrary, their economic and food sovereignty must be respected, a major plan to finance sustainable investments including social and environmental clauses and jointly mobilizing cheap credit for co-development actions, should be discussed and developed. Cooperation policies must be accompanied by significant progress in respecting human rights and democracy, not conditioning aid according to the international Monetary Fund's criteria. Similarly, the cooperation agreement with the State of Israel should be suspended after the Gaza massacres and the continuation .... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The human rights situation in Egypt is constantly deteriorating. Of course, we need to work with the government there and stay in the conversation and try to use our influence to improve this dire situation. Nevertheless, the continuation of the negotiations on DCFTA is more than just a contact, they are more than just a technical discussion. They mean that we ignore the many serious violations of human rights and support the government, give it international recognition. This is really a slap in the face for all those who are suffering from the current human rights violations. I would therefore like to ask you, Commissioner, whether you are suspending the negotiations on this until there is progress on human rights in Egypt or until we can at least see the will to do so.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the ministerial meeting of the Union for the Mediterranean on 30 September will be the official opportunity to resume discussions on various agreements between the Union and the Mediterranean countries, and it will also be an opportunity to really assert the interests of all Europeans. Commissioner, I am well aware of the agreement already signed with Morocco, the same agreement that invaded our market for very low-cost agricultural products in direct competition with those of my country, an agreement signed to allow certain European heavyweights to export their industrial products to Morocco, thus sacrificing the agricultural production of the Mediterranean states. I therefore call on the Commission to negotiate for Europe, and not just for certain States, and to require future partners to comply with our standards of rights and safety, especially food, in order to protect our consumers and make competition fairer.  I call for emphasis to be made on workers' rights and on the regularisation of unemployed work in small and medium-sized overseas companies, because such diverse working conditions create competition that our small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe are unable to sustain. Our small and medium-sized entrepreneurs are investing more and more overseas. That is why we must work to create sound regulatory frameworks that guarantee safe investments, make it easier for them to obtain visas, as I have already said, for work purposes and to coordinate the different European strategies for small and medium-sized enterprises. Guarantees, financing, distribution of information and networking, with a view to the creation of bilateral chambers of commerce and an extension of the mandate of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Finally, I would ask you not to forget the importance of cultural services: strengthening the tourism sectors, providing scholarships and strengthening the Erasmus and Da Vinci Euromed programmes are necessary to create the links and knowledge that will move the economy of the future. Commissioner, there is much to gain or much to lose from these agreements; it all depends on how Europe is able to play its cards.

name: Louis Aliot (NI). -
text: Mr President, cooperation between the states of the European Union and the Mediterranean, yes! The establishment of a free trade area, that is, the gradual erasure of economic borders first, human then, no! That the European Union should invest in the countries of the South for balanced development, also in a desire to loosen the migration stranglehold and, in the long run, to reverse the flows from the North to the South, is now an investment for our future. To defend our peasants, our workers, our industries but also our cultures and our civilization, the development of the South is a vital necessity.  But not at any price! We must first ensure our security by conditioning these aids on political stability, respect for minorities and the fight against wild immigration. Finally, we must ensure that every euro spent there is used with local businesses and labour or, failing that, with European companies, which will prevent us from indirectly financing the Chinese or American economies.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the objectives of neighbourhood policy are to create an area of stability, prosperity and democracy and a framework to promote peaceful conflict resolution. This task is not simple: the political and economic challenges facing our neighbours are enormous and our commitment to support a transition in these countries to democratic societies must be stronger than ever. Reasons for this commitment do not lack: migratory pressure, which continues to increase; the threat to our security because of the instability of the area; the energy problems that force us to look to the Maghreb; or the economic potential for our economies to achieve a Mediterranean union with stable and growing countries. In this process of change, trade plays an essential role: we must continue to strengthen the process of trade integration between the countries on the southern bank of the Mediterranean and also between them with the European Union. In the negotiations to achieve these agreements, the Commission must ensure an ambitious level of liberalization in key areas such as services, investment and government procurement. At a time when much of the Commission's efforts and resources on the trade and external agenda are focusing on other geographical areas, I believe that strengthening integrity and trade integration with Euromed should be one of the European Commission's priorities.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Euro-Mediterranean partnership between the Union and the countries of the southern Mediterranean was initiated in 1995 by the Barcelona process. This is a political, economic and social partnership based on the principles of reciprocity, solidarity, co-development, themes that are dear to us.  Respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights is an essential element of association agreements. Such agreements underline the importance of economic, commercial and financial cooperation, but also, and equally, social, cultural and educational cooperation. I would like to speak here as a member of this Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality to remind us that this trade agreement must be an opportunity to improve respect for women's rights in general and, more specifically, women's access to education and employment, the role of culture and the media as key instruments for changing opinions on gender equality. It should also facilitate the creation and management of enterprises by women, improve women's access to financing mechanisms and tools, and develop vocational training.  On the other hand, I would like to commend the courage of these women who have been at the forefront of civil society movements in favour of democracy and human rights in Arab countries. Unfortunately, the fallout from all these revolutions raises fears of further marginalization of these women, women in general. They have also resulted in an increase in violence against them.  As you have seen, of course, progress remains to be made and I think we have a decisive role to play. It is our duty as partners in these agreements. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Tarabella, when you support the Arab revolutions, do you not think that the role and domination of women have unfortunately been seriously questioned in the countries you cite?

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Ferrand, I do not know if you have heard what I have said. I talked about the key role of women in a struggle for more democracy, more rights for them, but also for democracy.  Unfortunately, indeed, as I have said very clearly and verbatim, we can be disappointed with the consequences of these movements. Women should not be marginalized. Today, they seem more marginalized than before in some countries, and their role also seems more marginal. I believe that we must therefore take this situation into account at European level in order to make women play an important role in their country's economy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Madam President, speaking of women's rights, I think that in the so-called Arab spring, women played a very important role, but unfortunately later it didn't go the way it was supposed to. In any case, I am in favour of this agreement - an area of a peaceful neighbourhood needs to be created, because it is a framework for singaging conflicts. We need to help countries transition and I think the economy needs to be at the service of politics. Strengthening cooperation is a priority, and the basis of all this was the Barcelona Process in 1995.  I emphasize cooperation in all areas, but especially in the field of the environment, because we did not mention it much, and I think that we all have a common concern to take into account the Mediterranean Sea and the preservation of the environment. I believe that some countries from the state level can do a lot here, but also regional cooperation is very important and we expect the results of the meeting on September 30th, where it will show what can be done at the level of local government, self-government and regions.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the European Union represents and must continue to be a global landmark of economic and democratic development. To do this, Europe must continue to offer prospects for integration and collaboration with all neighbouring countries, both in the south and in the east. Coming from a former communist country, which has undergone a difficult transition, I can tell you that it is absolutely necessary for the democratisation and development of these countries to keep the borders open, especially for those who come from the younger generation. Only through continuous collaboration and trade can we lead these countries in the right direction, but this does not mean to discount our own principles, and we must continue to work to impose them, because open doors also mean, on the part of these countries, the agreement to respect our values. I also believe that it is very important that the Commission, the European Union and the Member States involve the eastern countries more in this cooperation in the future. Our experience can be a beneficial element in building collaboration between the entire European Union and the countries of the south, because the countries of the east also have experience that can be helpful in this direction.

name: Ivan Jakovčić -
text: Mr. President, I was looking forward when the Union for the Mediterranean initiative was launched, I also had the opportunity to work within ARLEM, to represent Europe in this part and I must say that I have become well acquainted with all the needs of our friends in the south of the Mediterranean. I definitely support this agreement, I support the negotiations, but it is really absolutely true and necessary to protect our interests, both global, those general from human rights to all that are the values of Europe and to those quite concrete and I will be very, very concrete - the problem of olive oil is for example one of those problems that exists when we talk about the competitiveness of our product on the world market , i.e. it is better to say, in our Europe itself because I know that a lot of olive oil is imported from the south of the Mediterranean, mixed with our olive oil and then sold as European olive oil. Of course, that's where I talk about quality. There are certainly more such examples, but for this example I know and therefore I want to point out that it is very important that we know the country of origin of each product.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, we are in favour of diversifying our trade relations. What we are calling for is that it is not only purely economic criteria governing these relations. And therefore, whatever the elimination of tariffs, etc., of course, this will only create enormous difficulties for these economies, as in Portugal we painfully know. And, therefore, what we demand are other criteria, social criteria, criteria based on respect for human rights, respect for the sovereignty of each country, in short, and complementarity logics that effectively bring mutual advantages to all the countries involved. And finally, I also support the question of Israel, which is exactly a finished example where I believe that the European Union should go much further, and not just in labelling, that is just naïve, because there are many ways around that. An effective embargo, we continue to believe that it is one of the possible solutions to solve the problem... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Udo Voigt (NI). -
text: Mr. President! We have heard a lot about fundamental rights and fundamental values in Europe. I wonder why the Commission is not reporting on the issue of the State of Israel in the Mediterranean countries.  The United Nations put the number of children killed since July 2014 at 500. Israel has also bombed at least 244 schools, including 45 United Nations schools.  In view of this blatant breach of international law and, in particular, the Geneva Convention on the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War, the Neighbourhood Agreement with Israel should be suspended, or at least it should be debated whether sanctions can be used to persuade the Israelis to hold the guilty and possibly to refer them to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me try to answer a number of questions that have been raised, some of them repeatedly. First of all, there were a number of questions on Egypt and the question as to whether we should negotiate a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement (DCFTA) at all, given the current human rights abuses. The Council gave the Commission a negotiating mandate for a DCFTA with Egypt in 2011. The actual launch of negotiations depends on the completion of a preparatory scoping process which has barely even started, so launching negotiations will depend on a joint decision by the EU and Egypt, and the Commission will keep Parliament informed in real time. It is very difficult to suspend something that has not yet started. As with any other prospective trade agreement, the Commission has commissioned an external consultant to undertake a trade sustainability impact assessment. This will examine the potential economic, social and environmental impact of an agreement. It will include a specific chapter on implications in the field of human rights, and on the side-lines of the Union for the Mediterranean Trade Ministerial Conference on 30 September I will have a bilateral meeting with the Egyptian Minister. On Morocco, we launched DCFTA negotiations in March 2013. They have progressed well in the course of the four negotiating sessions that have already been held and both sides share the common objective of concluding a DCFTA as soon as possible. Of course we will have to take into consideration mutual interests and priorities. Morocco has decided to launch accompanying studies on certain sectors that will be covered by the future DCFTA. Morocco has agreed with its business sector and civil society to take into consideration the results of these studies during the next negotiating rounds. In that context we have therefore agreed to postpone the fifth round of negotiations. However, there is no suspension of negotiations. Technical contacts will continue during this period to ensure the continuity of the negotiating process. The Union for the Mediterranean Trade Ministerial Conference will be an opportunity for further discussion with the Moroccan Trade Minister. I hope that we can resume the formal negotiations this year and that we will be in a position to conclude them next year. The DCFTA negotiations with Morocco are politically important since they will set a precedent for other partners in the regions such as Tunisia, Jordan and Egypt. On Israel, the EU has a very clear position on the illegality of Israeli settlements. Therefore we have already ensured that products originating in the Israeli settlements do not benefit from preferential treatment when entering the EU market. An additional step is to follow the practice of certain Member States and further clarify the labelling of these products so that consumers are fully aware, when making their choice, that the product originates in Israel or in an Israeli settlement. The Commission, together with the European External Action Service, is gradually revising existing legislation on mandatory labelling, mostly for agricultural products, and has started the preparation of more general guidelines on the labelling of these products in order to help Member States to implement existing legislation on voluntary labelling. More generally, on a number of remarks that have been made about the principle of ‘more for more’, let me say that in all these DCFTAs and in the mandates for negotiating them, as in other trade agreements, meaningful reciprocal commitments on human rights will be included. In fact, we want to use these agreements to promote a strong human rights agenda. The DCFTA mandates were adopted on an individual basis to reflect the ‘more for more’ principle. On a political point, regarding ‘more for more’, what it means is more aid and more investment if more is done on political reform. What it also means is that we ourselves have to open our markets to the partner countries. This is not always easy to do in the context of these agreements, and Member States are not too flexible on the matter. On the other hand, I think we should also have a somewhat different approach in relation to visas, which is one of the very clear demands, and then, of course, the countries concerned should also agree to open their markets progressively. They have to assume their responsibilities: we also have to do that – in other words, the European Union also needs to assume its responsibilities and introduce more flexibility with these countries than is presently the case.
