name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. "Like any response to the popular aspirations expressed in the so-called Arab Spring, the EU responds to trade and free trade. Association agreements become pure free trade agreements, even if they are coupled with so-called mobility agreements where the only certainties are that we want more than ever to make the southern states the gendarmes of Europe with the consequences that we know for the rights of migrants. And in the interest of whom: Europeans and especially multinationals, in defiance of those of the people. In Morocco, civil society is fighting because it fears that exports of European products will be promoted at the expense of Moroccans' economic, social and environmental rights. In Tunisia, the EU is trying to force its way before the next election deadlines with the same fears as in Morocco, especially for agricultural products. And let us not talk about Israel, where we turn a blind eye to violations of international law in defiance of the terms of the Association Agreement. The EU's ultra-liberal excesses continue on both sides of the Mediterranean while other policies are possible, promoting cooperation, sustainable development and the free movement of workers. "

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Daniel Caspary, Christofer Fjellner, Salvatore Cicu, Santiago Fisas Ayxel, Gabrielius Landsbergis, Franck Proust, Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl, Tokia Sa'fi, Adam Szejnfeld, Iuliu Winkler, Bendt Bendtsen, Reimer Böge, Seen Kelly, Gabriel Mato, Fernando Ruas, Jozsef Szjer, Jaroslaw Leszek Wasa, Pablo Zalba Bidegain, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and Emma McClarkin on behalf of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists on GSP+ (Generalised System of Preferences) and compliance with the Convention on the Minimum Age of Admission to Employment: the case of Bolivia (O-000062/2014 - B8-0031/2014) – (2014/2837(RSP)).

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: Developer. - Mr. President, according to the UN, child labour has been steadily declining since 2000; reduced by a third. And while we are advancing globally in this aspect, the Bolivian Congress passed a new law on children's rights on July 2 this year in which the lowest employment age was reduced from 14 to 12 years, and in the case of self-employment to 10 years of age. Thus, Bolivia is the only country in the world that allows 10-year-olds to work. These children in Bolivia do, in some cases, heavy physical work such as working in sugar beet fields or mines. The Bolivian government's argument is to contribute to this law that child labour is necessary in Bolivia to reduce poverty.  However, the work of children may seem like a solution to some - it can only be short-term, because in fact such a solution only amplifies, only increases poverty in the long run. That is why UNICEF has also expressed concern about the non-compliance of Bolivian law with the international convention on the lowest employment age. And this is one of the conventions that states must ratify if they wish to meet the criteria for obtaining and using the GSP, i.e. the general system of preferences.  Bolivia has ratified the convention on the lowest age and has been using customs preferences since January 1 this year. However, shortly after it began to use customs preferences, Eva Morales' government nevertheless changed this law and thereby gives the impression that the European Union and the European Parliament had been deceived.  That is why we have referred this question to the European Commission from the European People's Party, I will read it in the original in English: 'Does the Commission believe that this new legislation prima facie puts Bolivia in breach of the Minimum Age Convention, which is one of the conventions that must be complied with in order to benefit from GSP+? Furthermore, can the Commission indicate whether it will analyse in detail the content of Bolivia's new children's rights bill, taking this analysis into account in Bolivia's GSP+ "scorecard" in order to decide whether or not any serious failure has been identified in its effective implementation of this convention?'

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the Commission is aware of Bolivian Law No 548 on Children and Adolescents, adopted on 17 July 2014, which aims to ensure a high level of protection for children in Bolivia. For example, UNICEF has commended this law for reinforcing Bolivia’s commitments under ILO Convention No 182 on the ‘prohibition and immediate action for the elimination of the worst forms of child labour’, which Bolivia ratified in 2003. Moreover, the Bolivian Ombudsman found that the law has strengthened the legal framework in key areas relating to the protection of children, such as infanticide, access to health and education, identity, and the right to childhood and life. However, both organisations have expressed concerns over the provisions which lowered the minimum working age for children in an apparent contradiction of Bolivia’s commitments under ILO Convention No 138 concerning the minimum age for admission to employment. The Commission shares these concerns. We are actively engaging the Bolivian Government on this issue, and in parallel it is consulting the ILO to assess these provisions in the light of Convention No 138. The GSP monitoring is an integral part of the revised GSP+ system and its aim is to help the Commission assess GSP+ beneficiaries and the effective implementation of the GSP+ conventions. In the case of Bolivia, the Commission has already issued a scoreboard to Bolivia in February 2014 addressing aspects of the implementation of relevant GSP+ Conventions which require further work or clarification. Bolivia has been cooperating with the Commission and provided a reply in May 2014.  Following this initial exchange, the Commission officially communicated with the Bolivian authorities on 18 July 2014 – one day after the adoption of the Bolivian law that is of concern to honourable Members of the European Parliament. The Commission is expecting Bolivia’s comments on the issue by today. The Commission will review Bolivia’s response and liaise with the ILO – the monitoring body for Convention No 182 – before deciding on the next steps. We will keep Parliament and the Member States informed accordingly.

name: Franck Proust
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, across Bolivia we are facing the reality of a developing country. We support Bolivia by giving it privileged access to the European Union market as part of commitments related to the GSP generalised preference system.  However, the new legislation of July 2014 in Bolivia allows children aged 10 and over to work in a framework that protects them. Of course, in view of the current situation, this is a step forward, especially since it is a demand of child labourers, but a step towards what? Among Bolivia's commitments, it is clear that the Minimum Age Convention must be ratified or even respected. So my question is whether Bolivia is still living up to its commitments. The values we uphold prioritize access to education over child labour. In Europe, we have student federations. In Bolivia, they have federations of child labourers. This reality, Commissioner, cannot be denied, even if it is disturbing. There is, of course, a technical and legal decision to be made. Is Bolivia living up to its commitments under the agreements? But there is also a political response to be made. To exclude Bolivia from the GSP is to condemn it even more. But allowing our partner countries to deviate from the rules is not acceptable. It is also intolerable to imagine that we will soon see products from the work of 10-year-old children on our territory. Commissioner, the choice is... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, I agree with your prudence. I think your answer has been prudent. And I believe that a decision by the Commission on Bolivia, by this law, would be hasty and cause greater ills. Precipitated because, as you said, we must wait for the explanation of the Government of Bolivia, which has it. Secondly, because the ILO, as you said, is going to produce a report which is going to be the most important report on what this violation of this fundamental Convention is of the right to work of children. And thirdly, because I believe that, honestly, it must be acknowledged that the Government of Bolivia has wanted to respond to a real problem and that 60% of children in Bolivia work, ladies and gentlemen. Unfortunately, 90% of children's work in Bolivia is informal, it is out of the law. The problem, of course, is that the doubt we all have is whether it is good that there is a protective law on child labour or, on the contrary, there better not be. I believe that we must be cautious and above all, these countries must be respected. I was appointed President of parliament's delegation to the EuroLat Assembly a few days ago. I know Latin America, I talk to Latin American ambassadors and they ask us not to give them democracy lessons every day. And this is already very important. Let's respect them. Let's talk to them. Let us work to advance the fulfilment of fundamental rights. But above all – and remembering this seems very important to me – let us not condemn children in Bolivia to enslaved work. I believe that we must take this reality into account in order to make the most appropriate and prudent decision, and my group is, Commissioner, with your words of prudence and waiting.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the rules on child labour in Bolivia are fully in breach of international conventions in this area, both in terms of employees and self-employment, but it is mandatory to draw attention to two issues. The defence of the rights of minors is a universal cause that does not understand borders; nor should it depend on the economic power, dimension or interests we have in countries that consent to child exploitation.  On the other hand, it is very striking that a rule like the one at issue is considered in Bolivia to be a step forward for the victims of exploitation and is also the result of agreement with some of the organizations that are associated with the children who work, nothing less than because it makes visible and gives rights to a part of the population that , for a variety of cultural, economic or socio-political reasons, is part of Bolivia's workforce. Among the children who work in that country are the more than nine hundred who leave the streets every year, teenagers living from abuse or misery and even those who consider that working at the age of ten is part of the educational process. That is why I ask whether, in addition to the sanctioning position, further action is taken to strike the root of this evil in the countries in which it occurs, and whether steps like this, by making this problem visible, can help to solve it. I would also like to know how many GSP countries have problems posed by non-compliance with the Child Labour Convention, and how many of those who aspire to integrate could have them.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner and, in particular, Mr Stier, I would like to thank Mr Stier for his work on this The new Children and Youth Act gives children in Bolivia rights that do not exist or are not implemented in most Member States of the European Union. Children there are independent legal entities. In my own country, Germany, the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is not yet as far-off as in Bolivia.  Bolivia has chosen and found a way instead of paternalism, which directly involved the children in the drafting of the law. In line with ILO Convention 138, Bolivia has declared its goal of developing society by 2020 in such a way that no child needs to work. Today, as has already been said, the reality is, unfortunately, even different: 750 000 children have to work. They have even formed their own trade union and pushed for their status of illegality to be ended. That has been achieved. Dangerous work remains prohibited in accordance with ILO Convention 182. Exemptions are possible for work carried out by children in need, but only if their right to access to education and health is not restricted. I think we should ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bodil Ceballos
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In my group, we see the law, which has some shortcomings, yet as a good first step in improving children's and young people's rights in Bolivia in general, not least because it has a rights-based focus and sees children as subjects rather than objects. The 348 articles include, inter alia, a ban on discrimination on grounds of sex or disability, a complaint, the right of children and young people to a safe environment, education, information, privacy, etc.m.  Rather, instead of threatening withdrawing aid, we think that the Commission should participate more financially, to actually support the implementation of the law and also to be able to contribute to children's schooling. Is that something the Commission would be willing to do? Someone has also mentioned this organisation for child labourers who have also participated in this work to develop the law.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me first of all say that the EU is not the monitoring body in this respect. We are not the monitoring body for the Minimum Age Convention; that is the task of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and we rely on the ILO’s report before taking the next steps. This is done to keep the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP+) objective because it grants tariff preferences unilaterally. However, you should not ignore the leveraging power of GSP+. Our partners know that there are legal conditions and that if they are not met we can temporarily withdraw the benefits of the scheme. That is why we are in touch with the Bolivian authorities to remind them not to take GSP+ status for granted. On the matter itself, at first sight it would seem that this law could be in contravention of ILO Convention No 138, which stipulates 15 years as the minimum working age for children but allows developing countries, such as Bolivia, to reduce that limit to 14 years. At the same time, ILO Convention No 138 specifies that children between the ages of 13 and 15 – or 12 and 14 for developing countries – may do light work as long as it does not hinder their education or harm their health. Bolivia ratified ILO Convention No 138 in 1997. When the new law was adopted, Vice-President Álvaro García Linera stated that the lower working age reflected the reality in Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America. On the other hand, the Bolivian law overall has been praised by UNICEF and by the Bolivian Ombudsman as reinforcing the protection of children, with the exception of two provisions lowering the working age. However, the ILO supervisory system has not yet been in a position to assess the compatibility of the law with Convention No 138. The ILO Committee of Independent Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations (CEACR) will assess the compatibility of the Bolivian law with ILO standards in its November-December 2014 session. CEACR is the competent authority within the ILO to make such an assessment. The Commission is fully aware of the issues raised in the European Parliament questions and is taking the necessary steps to ensure that Bolivia’s actions are fully in line with its GSP+ commitments. It has officially expressed its concerns in writing to the Bolivian authorities and expects a reply by mid-September. We have not received it yet. Similarly the Commission is in contact with the ILO, seeking advice on the interpretation of the new Bolivian law.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The debate is closed.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: This is not the first time bolivia has been discussed as a state that does not comply with its international commitments and is quite generous in shaping its internal laws. It is therefore important for the Commission to consistently call for the latest law allowing child labour from 10 to 12 years, as this is in open contrast to international expectations. The Union shall not contribute directly or indirectly through its programmes. This goes back to violations of international obligations that require fair trial and which Bolivia continues to break, as in the case of Predecessor Tóásó, who has been imprisoned in this Latin American country for five and a half years without a final judgment in his case. I would like to reave the call for the relevant Decision of the European Parliament that Bolivia respect the most basic human rights , be it children or illegally detained citizens such as Predecessor Tóásó.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: József Nagy (PPE). -
text: Allow me to introduce myself in my first speech. I am Jozsef Nagy and I am from Slovakia, but I will nevertheless speak hungarian in my mother tongue. Looking at today's events, it is eerie for me to think about the future of peace in Europe. Ukraine, Gaza, Syria, Iraq are not as far away as many people think. Our relationship with Ukraine is determined by Putin because Europe is pulling us apart. Ten years ago, the citizens of my country and the Hungarians in Slovakia were happy to join the EU because, after 40 years of Communist and Russian rule, they saw freedom and the future as guaranteed here. Instead, today European values and integration are threatened by daily political interests. In fact, populist rhetoric is hampering unity. I ask, for example, Mr Farage, who in this House is vehemently arguing against the integration of the European Union, what is his message to the participants in this week's Scottish referendum? Are they better off with a breakaway? I wonder why...  (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Siôn Simon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Europe needs to focus more of its resources on advanced manufacturing and engineering. Making things has become terribly unfashionable but it is actually what we are good at in this part of the world. By ‘this part of the world’ I mean Europe and particularly my constituency of the West Midlands. Firms like Jaguar Land Rover, Hadley Industries and East End Foods are exporting all over the world and creating thousands of jobs as they do so, but they are desperate to fill those jobs with more and better science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM) graduates. We have got to be more active on skills if we are serious about growth. That is why the European Semester and the Youth Guarantee must prioritise training whatever the other pressures. Our young people need sustainable, quality jobs and we need to give them the tools.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Very often in our countries we worry that the European Parliament's activities are not of sufficient interest, even complaining about insufficient turnout in European Parliament elections.  Last week, however, three ordinary people from The New York Times arrived at our headquarters Polish, who at the same time did something quite extraordinary. Roman, Wojciech and Grzegorz went on foot on a pilgrimage all over Europe.They set off from Knox in Ireland, from Monte Cassino and from Hawthorn in Poland. They brought to the European Parliament a message of peace and an icon of St. Benedict written and blessed in war-torn Ukraine. I think it is a message, their love with which they came to the headquarters of the European institutions, their sacrifice, their efforts should be a model and an inspiration to all of us. And I hope that the icon of St. Benedict they brought will find a worthy place in our...

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, although it is clear today that in our mandate I will not have any new colleagues, i.e. obviously the enlargement negotiation process will take all these 5 years, yet we think that we must not stop the enlargement, that is, the negotiation process. In fact, I think we should inselate it because countries in Southeast Europe have concrete ambitions.  Of course, that I am thinking first of all about Serbia, Montenegro and Albania and the last summer talks I had with Prime Minister Vucic and Prime Minister Djukanovic show a determined will that Serbia-Montenegro, and of course we know that the same situation is in Albania, especially our colleagues and colleagues in parliament, that is, that they also get deputies and deputies.  Of course that means fulfilling all the obligations they have and there's nothing to discuss about it. I believe that the Balkans need peace, and peace can be called the European Union. That is why I call on us to give the citizens of these countries our perspective.

name: Iosu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, most Basque society has two political priorities: peace and self-determination. And a clear electoral majority supports it, as our presence in this Parliament also reflects. It is time to obtain all our rights as individuals and as a people, including also the right of Basque citizenship to be what it decides democratically.  And the resolution of the Basque political conflict is also a European issue. This Parliament has the opportunity to urge, again, the Spanish and French Governments to be courageous, to promote solutions and not to maintain policies and strategies of the past based on 'no' and revenge, as portrayed by the umpteenth political trial that will begin next week at the Spanish National Hearing against twenty-eight young people or the accident suffered by relatives of prisoners this weekend , the result of the dispersion policy. I encourage this Parliament to work for peace and self-determination in line with most Basque society.  That's our commitment!

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE). -
text: (He began his speech in Catalan)  Mr President, Catalonia is an old European nation, a political subject, aware that it is and even more so than it intends to achieve by acting in that capacity. And from Catalonia comes a powerful and clear voice, a democratic way to legitimize the decision you want to make about your own future. Europe cannot and should not be desented from the aspiration freely expressed by a society committed to building its own future, as much as that of Europe itself. Europe is changing. Scotland and Catalonia are also a positive illustration of this profound change: the change in the distribution of power between the "new Europe" under construction and each of its peoples, nations and states. We want more Europe to be better Catalonia. And we want to be a state to be a better Europe, to give you our most valuable <social, cultural and economic contribution.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr! I would like to point out to you that we are supplying 24 official languages here, and if you use another language here, the interpreting booths are neither ready nor able to translate this. So if you want you to be understood across the continent – and this Civic Chamber is there for that – then please use one of the official languages of the European Union.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, on 16 August 2014, 35 migrants crammed themselves into containers and docked themselves at Tilbury in my constituency. Sadly one died and, as tragic as this episode is, they have since tried to claim asylum. I think it would be wrong, and here is why. We are already known across Europe as ‘soft-touch Britain’, and this would only add to the United Kingdom being a soft touch. If we give asylum here, many more will put themselves in harm’s way in containers to come to the United Kingdom. We have proper processes in place to claim asylum in the UK and to migrate to the UK, and this is unfair to the wider community and to genuine migrants and asylum seekers. Next May, the British people and my constituents will be able to judge soft-touch Britain. They will be able to vote for UKIP, a party that rejects this Union and that will get our borders and our country back.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI). -
text: Mr President, Europe was never united. The European states were fighting against each other but we were doing well, we were developing. Now, Europe under the occupation of the European Union, is at a standstill, it has zero growth – and the reason is the European Union. The acquis communautaire is the reason why we do not develop. The European Union is the exact opposite to Europe. The acquis communautaire is the exact opposite of European values. What in Europe was called ‘good’, in the European Union is called ‘bad’. We can see the reason very clearly. We will see the first caliphate not from ISIS, we will see the caliphate in the south of France. Normality must be returned. The European Union is an artificial product and it stops the development of Europe. The reason is the European Union and the acquis communautaire.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to refer to a long-running dispute involving a number of Irish construction companies which have had a very difficult time with the Polish authorities in the last few years. This dispute goes back to 2012. In excess of EUR 250 million has been lost. Many hundreds of jobs in Ireland have been lost through poor procurement procedure and poor contract procedure, and this was also the subject of a letter by five other European Union countries to the Polish authorities. I am looking for three things: firstly I would like the Polish roads authority to engage with the complainants in a fair and honest way; secondly, I am asking the Polish authorities to enter immediately into independent mediation to resolve this dispute; and thirdly I would ask the Commission, in the presence of one of the Commissioners here this evening, at the very least to consider this matter more closely. We are talking about EU funds, EU structural funds, the funds of the EU taxpayer, and we need to ensure that those funds are spent properly, with proper procurement procedures. There are issues in this case that need to be resolved.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the Commission’s consultation on water closes next week so today, as a new Member, I am pleased to support the work done by everyone in this Parliament and beyond on the Right to Water Campaign. Partnerships with the private sector for expertise, innovation and research can be beneficial, but exploitation of water resources for commercial profit is not.  In my city of London we are still facing first-hand, through massive water bill rises, the shocking consequences of privatisation. We have a poorly-regulated monopoly private provider of water which last year paid well over EUR 100 million in dividends and interest payments to shareholders, and in the countries hardest hit by recession our own institutions in the EU have been attempting to insist on water privatisation despite international evidence against it.  It is time for the Commission to be bold. We want no more excuses about the lack of legal base or application of principles of neutrality. EU-wide measures to promote democratic public control of water are the only answer.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, the territorial problems in European nations such as the Basque Country, Catalonia or Flanders need solutions such as this week in Scotland: not to impose a solution which, as imposed, is never and not to prevent citizens from being able to debate and decide. In short: politics and democracy. In short: dialogue, agreements and citizen ratification. I therefore claim the content of the Strasbourg Declaration for European arbitration to equal the rights of all citizens of the Union when a Member State refuses to follow this simple script. These territorial tensions are further a symptom of the decline of traditional states and an opportunity to renew the concept of nation and to build the federal Europe in which parties like mine have been working for seven decades.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, 31 August 2014 last marked the 20th anniversary of the IRA’s cessation of military activity in Ireland – the pivotal moment in the Irish peace process – and, despite early setbacks, an inclusive talks process led to the historic Good Friday Agreement which created the space for those of different aspirations to strive for them through peaceful means. It was this inclusive dialogue that led to meaningful progress. In recent times, the principle of engaging in such dialogue has been found wanting within political unionism, and both the Irish Government and the British Government, but especially the latter, have largely disengaged from the process. EU institutions which have supported the Irish peace process need to be aware that flag protests, the breakdown of the Haas negotiations and the walkout by unionists from all-party talks some weeks ago threaten the political institutions that underpin the peace process in Ireland. I ask people here to encourage political unionism and the Irish and British Governments to re-engage in meaningful all-party talks to ensure that all outstanding elements of the Good Friday and subsequent agreements are implemented in full, so that the Irish peace process can continue to provide an example to conflicts around the world.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I wanted to draw attention to the horrific floods now hitting India and Pakistan, and not least the divided state of Kashmir, where we have seen hundreds of deaths, the displacement of thousands of people, and a huge loss of livelihood. These floods are likely to continue, and we are being told that they are the worst floods to hit Kashmir in decades. We are all aware of the fact that Kashmir is a flashpoint area, and we have seen recent incidents along the line of control – even during this current emergency. However, I think that we should be welcoming the mutual offers of assistance between the governments of India and Pakistan during these floods. I really want to urge the European Union to actively support engagement between those two governments over the questions of improved water management and disaster preparedness in that area. This is a real opportunity to bring governments together to actually work for the benefit of their people, rather than pursuing this ongoing conflict.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian economic crisis combined with the immigration emergency risks undermining the protection of fundamental rights by generating a Darwinian struggle among the weakest. , willing to risk his life by challenging the Mediterranean aboard a dinghy. Yesterday's news is yet another tragedy: two hundred and fifty people sunk off the libyan coast. Europe and individual Member States are devoting rivers of money to a system of flow management that is not always transparent and not without critical issues and speculation. So what can we do? Stronger action is needed in the countries of origin and transit of migrants. The proper management of European funds in the Member States must be monitored in order to prevent fraud and waste. The Dublin Regulation needs to be reviewed in order to achieve real solidarity and cooperation between the Member States. Humanitarian corridors must be set up so that migrants can reach their destination directly without risking their lives.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: Mr President, the decisions of the recent NATO summit in Wales are directed against the people because they increase the aggression of the imperialist alliance and increase the risks of a generalised imperialist war that peoples will pay dearly for with their blood. NATO, the United States and the European Union military exercises on the territory of Ukraine are already proving this, escalating the confrontation with capitalist Russia over the sharing of markets, energy sources and territories. Today's conference in Paris on the coordination of the military action of the Euro-Nato willing against the so-called 'jihadists' who themselves have armed themselves, gives impetus to plans to re-design borders and generalisation of confrontation in the wider region. It is a strategic choice of the European Union or an even greater link with NATO.  The responsibilities of the Greek government are enormous because it participates in all the aggressive plans of the European Union and NATO. The Communist Party of Greece demands an immediate halt to all participation of the Greek armed forces in European Union and NATO missions and fights for the country's release from both the European Union and NATO for popular power and sovereignty.... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: László Tőkés (PPE). -
text: Hungarians in Romania are unethly in favour of the territorial autonomy of szeklerland in Transylvania. The Romanian parties and the Romanian Government itself are strongly opposed to any form of minority self-determination and, in contrast to the anti-Hungarian press propaganda of the mainstream media, are pursuing a hostile campaign against the autonomy of half a million Szekler-Hungarian communities. The Romanian intelligence service is inciting against Hungarian autonomy like the old Communist political police. The Supreme Judicial Council brands legitimate Hungarian aspirations as an unconstitutional attack in violation of the principle of independence of the powers. I call on the President, the European Parliament, to protect Hungarians in Transylvania from unfounded, chauvinistic attacks and to support our legitimate and democratic autonomy efforts.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D). -
text: This afternoon, in a brief debate, it was raised whether it was still worth dealing with Hungary in plenary. One of my colleagues, a fellow Member, said that there was no new development. I'd like to say there is! The Hungarian Prime Minister, for example, recently called NGOs agents of foreign powers. He harasses Hungarian NGOs with the tax authorities and the police. I think it is more important to state that this is not a simple Hungarian matter, it is a European matter! This is the first time that the Prime Minister of an EU country is seeking to consolidate his own political power against the core values, principles and ideals of the European community. I think that it is our fundamental task as MEPs to speak out on this issue, to rise to the fore and say: this is a European matter, we must defend European politics, the European community!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, a large part of Greece's public debt is in the hands of the European Central Bank, which bought Greek government bonds on the secondary market during the crisis at a discount of at least 40%. Thus, the ECB paid EUR 35 billion, but requires that the nominal value of these bonds, which amounts to EUR 53 billion, be repaid. That is, a profit of EUR 22 billion. In this way, Mr. Dragi and his company, by selling "air of sleuth", are profiting unashamedly and insinually at the expense of the poor Greek people.  For this year alone, the Greek people will pay a "hat" to the ECB of 4 billion euros and, for this reason, the mnemonic government in Athens has imposed with ENFIA unaffordable taxes on the real estate of Greeks. However, the ECB's role is not to profit at the expense of the citizens of the European Union. Thus, it is both legal and ethical to "tire" these ECB bonds and to pay Greece only the capital paid by the ECB to buy these bonds, plus an interest rate of 0.15%.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, in June 2012 the EU Council agreed to break the link between banks and sovereigns. The Summit statement spoke of the Euro Group examining the situation of the Irish financial sector in the context of using the ESM to retrospectively recapitalise Irish banks. Subsequently, there was some roll-back on this agreement, but just one month later a joint statement from Enda Kenny and Angela Merkel said that Ireland was a special case. Jean-Claude Juncker said earlier this year: ‘I think there must be some degree of retroactivity’ in the ESM, ‘otherwise it will lose most of its sense’. Yet to this day we have made no progress on this issue and, in case you did not know, Eurostat confirms that Ireland, which has less than 1% of the population of the EU, carried 43% of the net cost of the banking crisis. We now have banking union therefore the EU cannot renege on its promises. The ESM must be used to retrospectively recapitalise Irish banks – otherwise we will have been betrayed by our partners.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, an EU and Irish citizen, 17-year-old Ibrahim Halawa, was arrested in August 2013 amongst clashes between pro- and anti-Morsi supporters while on holiday in Egypt. One year on, he is still languishing in an Egyptian jail with no charges brought against him. No book of evidence has been submitted and Ibrahim has had to endure horrific conditions including physical abuse. Both Amnesty International and the human rights organisation Reprieve have investigated Ibrahim’s case and have found no justification for his incarceration. On 12 August Ibrahim’s case was due to be heard as part of the notorious mass trials which take place without legal representation. Due to the hundreds of defendants presented before the judge in one go, he walked out in protest, leaving a teenager jailed without charge, unable to finish his final exams at school and progress to further education with his friends. So I am calling on the EU to explicitly request his release and I will be seeking a meeting with the new High Representative as soon as possible to ensure that everything that can be done at an EU level is being done.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, at this meeting we will be debating the European Union budget for 2015 of around EUR 150 billion. Let us remember that it is EUR 150 billion taken from the pockets of citizens, that it is not money that has fallen from the sky. Many of you may think that money redistributed through Brussels in this way helps to live a better life in Europe. I think that's a lot of conceit, and I think the opposite. I believe that money redistributed in this way is bad for the economy, that it increases corruption, and that it increases the national debt. First, subsidies are money that an entrepreneur receives at the expense of someone else. Thus, the market is won by the person who receives the subsidies and not by the one who offers better services to consumers. The more money is redistributed, the greater the corruption. Thirdly, poorer countries in particular are taking out more and more loans just to raise money to co-finance these European subsidies. In short, I think this redistributed money is bad for the economy, and I think we could do without... (He removed the speaker's word.)

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE). -
text: Mr President, small, regional airports have a vital role to play in the economic development of their regions. I would like the new Commission-designate to focus on those airports and to ensure that investment is provided so that they can continue to be the engines of the regions in which they are located and can contribute to an efficient and effective transport system that allows regions to take full advantage of the internal market and to trade on a global scale. EU enlargement means there are greater travel distances within the Union, so it is more important than ever that regions are served by airports. We also need to promote global accessibility: it is well known that, when companies are locating to or investing in an area, international accessibility is very important and the availability of a local airport is key to their location requirements. As the Union enlarges, tourism is another area where we can create great employment opportunities. I would like the Commission, in its next term, to ensure investment in our airports ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D). -
text: Mr President, over EUR 300 million has been lost from unprecedented rainfall and flooding in Bulgaria in the last 3 months alone. The disasters left hundreds of people without a roof. The economy and agriculture will recover for years to come. Unfortunately, not only South-East Europe and the Balkans are affected by climate change.  Nature refutes the veracity of our own budget accounts and the drastic reduction of the Solidarity Fund. However, at the beginning of this year we changed the regulation here in the European Parliament to make the absorption of funds more flexible.  By the end of this month, the European Commission must also make the rules under which countries will use these funds. In the face of Mr de Guht, who is here, I call on the European Commission to do everything possible for a working document, to be able to make upfront payments to the most affected areas, and also for additional funds where they go even outside the framework of the Regulation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, tonight I want to emancipate the issue of the rights of Croats in Serbia, Croats as minorities of which there are just over 57,000 according to the 2011 census. The occasion is a recent donation from serbia's president, Nikolic, textbooks for Croats bunjevce in Subotica and elementary school students in Cyrillic.  It is a move that represents the continuity of the watering-up of the Croatian corpus and the Croatian minority in Serbia. We do not think this is good; this is a policy that has been in place since the early 1990s, I believe that the European Commission should insist within the framework of accession negotiations - Chapters 23 and 24, that the issue of respect for the 2004 bilateral agreement between Croatia and Serbia should be one of the elements for Serbia's further path to the European Union. We expect to see Croats in Serbia's representative bodies as well, and to provide funding for the language, education, culture of Croats in Serbia.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the waste crisis in Italy, and especially in southern Italy, has now become cyclical and the disposal system is not working, despite the fact that the populations are showing goodwill, as shown by the figure for increasing separate collection rates.  We are therefore witnessing a progressive and inexorable worsening of living conditions and the already known responsibilities in the field of waste disposal and recycling, so much so that Italy has been declared in default for violation of the directives on hazardous waste and landfill. The sanction is well deserved, and how could it not be if there are four hundred twenty-two areas at risk, two hundred eighteen illegal landfills and numerous forgotten and never reclaimed sites? It is also true, however, that an exemplary sanction must go hand in hand with an attempt to change the Union's intervention, which has so far perhaps not been effective enough. A proposal for a directive on waste and packaging is now being studied. This is our opportunity to strengthen European action, using the principles of the circular economy, a stricter alignment of definitions and prior controls and extended producer responsibility, of restrictions on municipal waste by 2030. I am sure I find the consensus of all of you, ladies and gentlemen, to turn a tragedy into a resource of our communities.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE). -
text: In Slovenia, we have repeatedly opposed the opatic installation of gas terminals in the Gulf of Trieste, in the direct border between Slovenia and Croatia. It is an area where about 100,000 people live, an area where there are two important ports – Koper and Trieste, an area marked by tourism. Therefore, the last procedure of placement of gas terminals some away from the border for Slovenia is unacceptable, and it is unacceptable, above all, the procedure by which these terminals are located, because Slovenian environmental organisations, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia and other important actors were not involved in this process. Therefore, in Slovenia we expect Slovenia and Italy to agree on the installation of gas terminals and that the process is carried out in accordance with European norms.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I have asked to intervene to signal a recent statement by Prime Minister Victor Ponta. I quote: "The effects on Romanian society left by the ten years of the Traian Basescu regime are quite similar to those left by the Nazi regime in Germany". I address my fellow socialists, the political family of the Romanian Prime Minister. Do any of you agree with such a statement? Can a democracy in the European Union be compared to a totalitarian regime? Do you think that a criticism of an adversary, liberal or conservative, can go as far as trivializing the crimes of the Nazi regime? Is the crisis crossed by Europe synonymous with the Holocaust? Do you think Victor Ponta represents a socialist sensibility? If your answer, fellow socialists, is 'no', you should say it publicly, because Prime Minister Ponta wants to be President Ponta in two months' time. You can't stop it, only Romanian voters can do it. However, you can explain the rules of democratic confrontation.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: That concludes this item.
